Step 3: Attempt to submit the form; UI should display a message indicating that the session has timed out and offer an option to resume from where they left off
Step 4: Click on 'Resume' button or similar action provided by the application
Step 5: Verify that all previously entered data is still present in the account creation form, allowing the user to complete the process
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After session timeout, the application should display a message indicating that the session has expired and provide an option to resume account creation. All entered data must be preserved.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: User account creation with minimum required fields
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that a user can create an account using the minimum required fields as specified in the requirement.
preconditions: A valid API endpoint for user registration is available
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/register with header Content-Type: application/json
Step 2: Include request body with minimum required fields: {"username": "minuser", "email": "min@example.com", "password": "P@ssw0rd"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code is returned indicating successful creation of the user account
Step 4: Verify response body contains a unique user ID for the newly created account
Step 5: Attempt to log in with the same credentials and verify login success (HTTP 200 status code)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user account is successfully created with a unique ID and can be logged into using the provided credentials.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Account creation fails with invalid email format
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that attempting to create an account with an improperly formatted email address results in a validation error.
preconditions: A valid API endpoint for user registration is available
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/register with header Content-Type: application/json
Step 2: Include request body with an invalid email format: {"username": "invaliduser", "email": "invalid-email.com", "password": "P@ssw0rd"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 400 status code is returned indicating a bad request due to validation failure
Step 4: Check response body for error message specifying the invalid email format
Step 5: Attempt to register with the same credentials and verify that no account is created
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system returns an HTTP 400 status code with a specific error message indicating that the email format is invalid, and no account is created.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Account creation with maximum allowed username length
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that a user can create an account using the maximum allowed length for the username field.
preconditions: A valid API endpoint for user registration is available
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/register with header Content-Type: application/json
Step 2: Include request body with a username of maximum length (30 characters): {"username": "maxusernamelength", "email": "max@example.com", "password": "P@ssw0rd"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code is returned indicating successful creation of the user account
Step 4: Verify response body contains a unique user ID for the newly created account
Step 5: Attempt to log in with the same credentials and verify login success (HTTP 200 status code)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user account is successfully created with a username of the maximum allowed length and can be logged into using the provided credentials.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle invalid email format during account creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system provides an appropriate error message when a user attempts to create an account with an invalid email address.
preconditions: Email field is visible and editable
test_steps: Step 1: Enter an invalid email format (e.g., 'invalidemail') in the Email field
Step 2: Click on the 'Next' button to proceed with account creation
Step 3: Verify that a validation error message is displayed next to the Email field
Step 4: Check if the error message states 'Please enter a valid email address.'
Step 5: Ensure no new user account has been created in the system
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the entered email is invalid, and no user account should be created.

test_data.expected_error_message: Please enter a valid email address.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle password length below minimum requirement during registration
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system provides an error message when a user attempts to create an account with a password shorter than the required minimum length.
preconditions: Password field is visible and editable
test_steps: Step 1: Enter a password that is less than 8 characters (e.g., 'pass') in the Password field
Step 2: Click on the 'Next' button to proceed with account creation
Step 3: Verify that a validation error message is displayed next to the Password field
Step 4: Check if the error message states 'Password must be at least 8 characters long.'
Step 5: Ensure no new user account has been created in the system
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the password is too short, and no user account should be created.

test_data.expected_error_message: Password must be at least 8 characters long.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle duplicate email during registration process
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system provides an error message when a user attempts to create an account with an email address that is already registered.
preconditions: Email field is visible and editable
test_steps: Step 1: Enter an existing email address (e.g., 'existinguser@example.com') in the Email field
Step 2: Click on the 'Next' button to proceed with account creation
Step 3: Verify that a validation error message is displayed next to the Email field
Step 4: Check if the error message states 'This email address is already registered.'
Step 5: Ensure no new user account has been created in the system
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the email address is already registered, and no user account should be created.

test_data.expected_error_message: This email address is already registered.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test: User Authentication and Role-Specific Redirect
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the performance of user authentication upon login and subsequent role-specific redirection.
preconditions: User account created with valid credentials
User has a specific role assigned
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/login with header Content-Type: application/json
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "user@example.com", "password": "secure_password"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned with JWT token in response
Step 4: Send GET request to /api/user/role with header Authorization: Bearer <JWT_token>
Step 5: Validate the user is redirected to a specific role-specific page within 1 second
Step 6: Verify that the UI elements for the role-specific page are loaded correctly
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user is authenticated successfully and redirected to their specific role's dashboard within 1 second with all UI elements loaded correctly.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test: Concurrent User Logins for Different Roles
phase2_test_cases.description: Evaluate the system's ability to handle concurrent user logins with different roles.
preconditions: Multiple user accounts created with various roles
System is in a stable state
test_steps: Step 1: Simultaneously send POST requests to /api/login for 50 users from different roles
Step 2: Include request body for each user: {"username": <user_email>, "password": <secure_password>}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned for all login attempts within 1 second per attempt
Step 4: Send GET requests to /api/user/role for each authenticated user with their respective JWT tokens
Step 5: Validate that each user is redirected to the correct role-specific page within 1 second
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All users are authenticated successfully and redirected to their specific role's dashboard within 1 second, with no system downtime or errors.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test: User Login Under High Load Conditions
phase2_test_cases.description: Assess the system's performance under high load conditions for user login.
preconditions: System is in a stable state
User accounts are ready for testing
test_steps: Step 1: Simultaneously send POST requests to /api/login for 500 users
Step 2: Include request body for each user: {"username": <user_email>, "password": <secure_password>}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned for all login attempts within 1 second per attempt
Step 4: Send GET requests to /api/user/role for each authenticated user with their respective JWT tokens
Step 5: Validate that each user is redirected to the correct role-specific page within 1 second
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All users are authenticated successfully and redirected to their specific role's dashboard within 1 second, with no system downtime or errors during high load conditions.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify JWT token validation upon user login
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system validates a valid JWT token during user authentication and redirects to role-specific dashboard.
preconditions: User account is created with proper credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the login page of the application
Step 2: Enter valid username and password in the 'Username' and 'Password' fields respectively
Step 3: Click on the 'Login' button to initiate authentication process
Step 4: Capture the JWT token from the HTTP response header after successful login
Step 5: Send a GET request to '/api/user/dashboard' with Authorization header set to 'Bearer <captured_jwt_token>'
Step 6: Verify that the system redirects to the role-specific dashboard page upon receiving the valid JWT token
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should successfully validate the provided JWT token and redirect the user to their role-specific dashboard page with a HTTP status code of 200 OK.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: User Authentication and Role-Based Access Control

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent unauthorized access to role-specific dashboard without JWT token
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system does not allow access to a user's role-specific dashboard if no valid JWT token is provided.
preconditions: User account exists and has a valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with a valid username and password
Step 2: Capture the JWT token from the HTTP response header after successful login
Step 3: Manually remove or invalidate the JWT token stored in local storage or cookies
Step 4: Attempt to access '/api/user/dashboard' without providing any JWT token
Step 5: Verify that the system returns a '401 Unauthorized' HTTP status code and does not redirect to the dashboard
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return a '401 Unauthorized' HTTP status code and not allow access to the role-specific dashboard if no valid JWT token is provided.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: User Authentication and Role-Based Access Control

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate JWT token expiration upon user login
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system does not authenticate a user with an expired JWT token.
preconditions: User account exists and has a valid but expired JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with a valid username and password
Step 2: Capture the JWT token from the HTTP response header after successful login
Step 3: Modify the 'exp' claim of the JWT token to set it to a past date, making the token expired
Step 4: Send a GET request to '/api/user/dashboard' with Authorization header set to 'Bearer <expired_jwt_token>'
Step 5: Verify that the system returns a '401 Unauthorized' HTTP status code and does not redirect to the dashboard
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return a '401 Unauthorized' HTTP status code and not allow access to the role-specific dashboard if an expired JWT token is provided.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: User Authentication and Role-Based Access Control

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify user authentication and role-specific redirection upon login
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that users are authenticated correctly and redirected to a page based on their role after logging in.
preconditions: User account with predefined role is created
Browser or mobile app is open
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the login page of the application
Step 2: Enter valid credentials for an admin user (username: 'admin', password: 'password') in the username and password fields
Step 3: Click on the 'Login' button
Step 4: Verify that the system redirects the user to a dashboard specific to the admin role within 5 seconds
Step 5: Check if the navigation bar includes links such as 'Tasks', 'Users', and 'Settings'
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should redirect the admin user to a dashboard with specific UI elements for their role, including navigation links relevant to an administrator's tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate error message clarity when incorrect credentials are entered during login
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that users receive clear and informative error messages if they enter incorrect credentials.
preconditions: User account exists with predefined role
Browser or mobile app is open
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the login page of the application
Step 2: Enter an invalid username (e.g., 'wronguser') and a valid password in the respective fields
Step 3: Click on the 'Login' button
Step 4: Verify that an error message appears indicating incorrect credentials within 1 second
Step 5: Check if the error message specifies both username and password requirements
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a clear error message stating 'Invalid credentials. Please check your username and password.' with specific details about the validation rules.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Evaluate mobile vs desktop experience for user authentication and role-specific redirection
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the login process and subsequent role-based navigation work seamlessly across both mobile and desktop platforms.
preconditions: User account with predefined role is created
Mobile app or browser on desktop is open
test_steps: Step 1: On a mobile device, navigate to the login page of the application
Step 2: Enter valid credentials for an admin user (username: 'admin', password: 'password') in the username and password fields
Step 3: Click on the 'Login' button
Step 4: Verify that the system redirects the user to a dashboard specific to the admin role within 5 seconds, with mobile-friendly UI elements
Step 5: On a desktop browser, repeat steps 1-3 and verify similar redirection and UI elements
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should redirect the admin user to a dashboard with role-specific navigation links on both mobile and desktop platforms, ensuring consistent and intuitive user experience.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Cross-Platform User Authentication and Role-Based Navigation

phase2_test_cases.test_title: User Authentication on iOS and Android Devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that users can authenticate upon login and are redirected to a role-specific dashboard on both iOS and Android devices.
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the application on an iPhone with iOS version 15.0
Step 2: Navigate to the login screen and enter a valid email address in the 'Email' field
Step 3: Enter a correct password in the 'Password' field and tap 'Login'
Step 4: Verify that the user is redirected to their role-specific dashboard within 5 seconds
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-4 on an Android device with version 12.0
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user should be successfully authenticated and redirected to their role-specific dashboard within 5 seconds on both iOS and Android devices.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Login Functionality Across Different Screen Sizes
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the login functionality works correctly across various screen sizes and resolutions.
test_steps: Step 1: Open the application on a device with a small screen (e.g., iPhone SE)
Step 2: Navigate to the login page and ensure all UI elements are clearly visible
Step 3: Enter valid credentials in the 'Email' and 'Password' fields
Step 4: Tap 'Login' and verify that the user is redirected to their dashboard within 5 seconds
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-4 on a device with a large screen (e.g., iPad Pro)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The login functionality should work seamlessly across different screen sizes and resolutions, ensuring all UI elements are clearly visible and the user is redirected to their dashboard within 5 seconds.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Login Performance on Different Network Types
phase2_test_cases.description: Test the login performance of the application under various network conditions (WiFi, 4G, 5G).
test_steps: Step 1: Connect a device to a WiFi network and open the application
Step 2: Navigate to the login page and enter valid credentials in the 'Email' and 'Password' fields
Step 3: Tap 'Login' and measure the time taken for authentication (should be less than 5 seconds)
Step 4: Disconnect from WiFi and connect to a 4G network, then repeat steps 2-3
Step 5: Connect to a 5G network and repeat steps 2-3
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The login process should complete successfully within less than 5 seconds on WiFi, 4G, and 5G networks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: User authentication and redirection upon successful login
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that a user is authenticated successfully upon login and redirected to the appropriate role-specific dashboard.
preconditions: The API endpoint for user login is accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/auth/login with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "john_doe", "password": "secure_password"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains JWT token in the form of a string starting with 'Bearer'
Step 5: Send GET request to /api/dashboard with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 6: Verify HTTP 302 status code indicating redirection
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user is successfully authenticated and redirected to their role-specific dashboard with an HTTP 302 status code.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Invalid user authentication attempt results in error response
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that an invalid login attempt returns the appropriate HTTP status code and error message.
preconditions: The API endpoint for user login is accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/auth/login with header Authorization: Bearer <invalid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "john_doe", "password": "wrong_password"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 401 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains error message indicating unauthorized access
Step 5: Send GET request to /api/dashboard with header Authorization: Bearer <invalid_jwt_token>
Step 6: Verify HTTP 401 status code is returned
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: An invalid login attempt results in an HTTP 401 Unauthorized response with a specific error message.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Rate limiting on user authentication attempts
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the API enforces rate limits to prevent brute force attacks during login.
preconditions: The API endpoint for user login is accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/auth/login with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "john_doe", "password": "secure_password"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 4: Repeat Step 1 and Step 2 for a total of 5 consecutive times within 60 seconds
Step 5: Send POST request to /api/auth/login with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 6: Verify HTTP 429 status code indicating rate limit exceeded
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After exceeding the allowed number of login attempts within a specified time frame, an HTTP 429 Too Many Requests status code is returned.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate user authentication and role redirection upon login
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that a user is authenticated correctly and redirected to the appropriate page based on their role.
preconditions: User account exists with predefined roles
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the login page of the application
Step 2: Enter valid credentials for a user with 'Admin' role into the username and password fields
Step 3: Click on the 'Login' button
Step 4: Verify that the user is redirected to the '/admin/dashboard' URL within 5 seconds
Step 5: Ensure that the page title contains 'Admin Dashboard'
Step 6: Check if all necessary UI elements for an admin are present and functional
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user should be successfully redirected to the '/admin/dashboard' page within 5 seconds, with a title containing 'Admin Dashboard', and all UI elements for an admin role must be present.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate mandatory fields during user registration
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that all required fields are validated and cannot be left empty when registering a new user.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Register' page of the application
Step 2: Leave the 'Username', 'Email', and 'Password' fields empty
Step 3: Click on the 'Submit' button
Step 4: Verify that error messages appear next to each mandatory field indicating they are required
Step 5: Ensure that no new user is created in the database after attempting registration with missing data
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Error messages should appear next to each mandatory field ('Username', 'Email', and 'Password') indicating that they are required, and no new user entry should be found in the database after attempting registration with missing data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate foreign key relationships during user role assignment
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that assigning a role to a user maintains proper database integrity and does not allow invalid role assignments.
preconditions: Role definitions exist in the system
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as an admin user with sufficient privileges
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Manage Users' section of the application
Step 3: Select a specific user and attempt to assign them a role that does not exist in the system (e.g., 'InvalidRole')
Step 4: Verify that an error message is displayed indicating that the selected role is invalid
Step 5: Ensure that no changes are made to the database for this invalid role assignment
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: An error message should be displayed indicating that the selected role 'InvalidRole' is not valid, and no changes should be made to the database for this invalid role assignment.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During User Authentication
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the application can handle network interruptions gracefully during user authentication and redirects to login page upon re-establishing connection.
test_steps: Step 1: Attempt to log in with valid credentials
Step 2: Simulate a network interruption by disabling internet connectivity
Step 3: Observe the application's behavior and ensure it displays an appropriate error message indicating network issues
Step 4: Re-enable internet connectivity after a short period (e.g., 10 seconds)
Step 5: Verify that the user is redirected back to the login page with an indication of successful reconnection or retry option available
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The application should display a network error message and allow users to attempt logging in again once the connection is restored, with clear instructions or retry options.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery After User Login
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the application can recover from a crash and restore user session upon reopening.
preconditions: Application has been forced to close
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as an existing user with valid credentials
Step 2: Forcefully terminate the application (e.g., through task manager or device settings)
Step 3: Reopen the application after a short delay (e.g., 5 seconds)
Step 4: Verify that the user is automatically logged in and redirected to their role-specific dashboard
Step 5: Check if all previously open tabs, data entries, or tasks are still available without requiring re-login
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon reopening the application after a crash, the user should be automatically logged in and redirected to their role-specific dashboard with all previous session data intact.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Test user authentication with minimum password length
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that a user cannot authenticate with a password shorter than the specified minimum length.
preconditions: Password reset link sent to email
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to login page and enter valid username
Step 2: Enter password of length 5 characters (minimum allowed - 6)
Step 3: Click 'Login' button
Step 4: Verify that an error message is displayed indicating the password must be at least 6 characters long
Step 5: Attempt to login again with a valid password and verify successful redirection
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the password must be at least 6 characters long, and the user should not be redirected to a role-specific page.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: User Authentication Module - Password Length Validation

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Test redirection after successful login for admin users
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that an admin user is redirected to the correct dashboard upon successful authentication.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to login page and enter valid admin username
Step 2: Enter a valid password for the admin user
Step 3: Click 'Login' button
Step 4: Verify that the system redirects the user to the admin dashboard within 2 seconds
Step 5: Check if all necessary UI elements (e.g., navigation menu, task list) are present on the admin dashboard
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should redirect the admin user to the admin dashboard within 2 seconds, and all necessary UI elements for an admin role must be present.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Test user authentication with maximum number of login attempts
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system locks an account after exceeding the maximum allowed login attempts.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to login page and enter valid username
Step 2: Enter incorrect password (e.g., 'wrongpassword') for 5 consecutive times
Step 3: Verify that the system displays an error message indicating account lockout after the fifth failed attempt
Step 4: Attempt to log in with correct credentials and verify that login is blocked due to account lockout
Step 5: Wait for the specified time period (e.g., 1 hour) and then try logging in again
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating account lockout after the fifth failed login attempt, and the user should not be able to log in until the specified time period has passed.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: User Authentication Module - Account Lockout Mechanism

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle invalid JWT token upon user login
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system correctly handles an invalid JWT token during user authentication and redirects to appropriate error page.
test_steps: Step 1: Obtain a valid user's credentials (email, password)
Step 2: Generate a JWT token using the obtained credentials
Step 3: Modify the generated JWT token to introduce an intentional error (e.g., changing a character in the token string)
Step 4: Send a POST request to /api/login with the modified JWT token in the Authorization header
Step 5: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized
Step 6: Confirm that the user is redirected to an error page indicating unauthorized access
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized and redirects the user to an error page with a message indicating unauthorized access.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle missing JWT token upon user login
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system correctly handles a scenario where no JWT token is provided during user authentication and redirects to appropriate error page.
test_steps: Step 1: Obtain a valid user's credentials (email, password)
Step 2: Send a POST request to /api/login without including the JWT token in the Authorization header
Step 3: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized
Step 4: Confirm that the user is redirected to an error page indicating unauthorized access
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized and redirects the user to an error page with a message indicating unauthorized access.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle expired JWT token upon user login
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system correctly handles an expired JWT token during user authentication and redirects to appropriate error page.
test_steps: Step 1: Obtain a valid user's credentials (email, password)
Step 2: Generate a JWT token using the obtained credentials
Step 3: Wait until the generated JWT token expires based on its expiration time set during creation
Step 4: Send a POST request to /api/login with the expired JWT token in the Authorization header
Step 5: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized
Step 6: Confirm that the user is redirected to an error page indicating unauthorized access
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized and redirects the user to an error page with a message indicating unauthorized access.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status for large dataset performance
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the system's ability to filter and display a large number of tasks based on their status within an acceptable time frame.
preconditions: System has at least 10,000 tasks with various statuses
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Click on 'Filter Tasks' dropdown menu and select 'All'
Step 3: Measure the time taken for all tasks to be displayed on the screen
Step 4: Verify that all 10,000 tasks are loaded within 5 seconds
Step 5: Check if the system remains responsive during task loading
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should load and display all 10,000 tasks within 5 seconds without any performance degradation or freezing.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance of filtering completed tasks with high concurrency
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system can handle multiple users simultaneously filtering for completed tasks without significant delays.
preconditions: Multiple user accounts are logged in
Each account has at least 1,000 tasks
test_steps: Step 1: Simultaneously log in as 5 different users
Step 2: Each user navigates to their task management page and selects 'Completed' status filter
Step 3: Monitor the response time for each user's request
Step 4: Verify that all requests are processed within 1 second
Step 5: Ensure no errors or timeouts occur during filtering
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All users should be able to filter and view their completed tasks within 1 second without any system performance issues.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance test for real-time status updates on task filtering
phase2_test_cases.description: Test the system's ability to update task statuses in real time and reflect these changes instantly when users filter tasks.
preconditions: System has at least 50 active tasks
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Mark a task as 'Completed' through the UI and observe the status change immediately
Step 3: Filter tasks by selecting 'Incomplete'
Step 4: Verify that the recently completed task is not shown in the filtered list
Step 5: Confirm that all other incomplete tasks are displayed correctly
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should reflect real-time status updates immediately after a task is marked as completed and ensure the filtered list does not include recently updated tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent unauthorized access to task status filter API endpoint
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that only authenticated users can access the API endpoint for filtering tasks by status.
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /tasks/status-filter without an Authorization header
Step 2: Verify that the server responds with HTTP 401 Unauthorized status code
Step 3: Log in as a valid user and obtain JWT token
Step 4: Send GET request to /tasks/status-filter with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 5: Verify that the server responds with HTTP 200 OK status code and returns task statuses
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized status code when the request is made without a valid JWT token, indicating that unauthorized access to the task status filter API endpoint is prevented.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent SQL Injection in Task Status Filter Query Parameter
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task status filter API endpoint is protected against SQL injection attacks.
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a valid user and obtain JWT token
Step 2: Send GET request to /tasks/status-filter with an invalid status parameter that includes SQL injection syntax, e.g., '?status=completed; DROP TABLE tasks--'
Step 3: Verify that the server responds with HTTP 400 Bad Request or similar error code indicating malformed input
Step 4: Send GET request to /tasks/status-filter with a valid status parameter, e.g., '?status=open'
Step 5: Verify that the server responds with HTTP 200 OK and returns tasks filtered by the specified status
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return an HTTP 400 Bad Request or similar error code when a request is made with an invalid status parameter that includes SQL injection syntax, indicating that the task status filter API endpoint is protected against such attacks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Task Status Filter UI Element
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task status filter UI element is protected against XSS attacks.
preconditions: Task management page with status filter dropdown exists
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a valid user and navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Attempt to inject malicious script into the status filter input field, e.g., '<script>alert('XSS')</script>'
Step 3: Verify that the injected script does not execute and no alert box appears on the screen
Step 4: Select a valid task status from the dropdown menu
Step 5: Verify that tasks are filtered by the selected status without any unexpected behavior
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should prevent the execution of injected scripts in the task status filter UI element, ensuring that no alert box appears on the screen when attempting to inject malicious code.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify clarity and placement of status filter UI elements
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the UI elements for filtering tasks by status are clearly visible, appropriately labeled, and placed in a logical location on both mobile and desktop interfaces.
preconditions: User is logged into the application
User has access to task management features
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Management page from the main dashboard
Step 2: On the Task Management page, locate the status filter UI element (expected to be a dropdown or set of checkboxes)
Step 3: On mobile devices, ensure that the status filter is easily accessible without requiring excessive scrolling or navigation through other sections
Step 4: Verify that each status option in the filter is clearly labeled and distinguishable from others (e.g., 'Pending', 'In Progress', 'Completed')
Step 5: On desktop devices, check if the status filter is placed prominently near task listings to facilitate quick filtering without navigating away
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The status filter UI elements are clearly visible and appropriately labeled on both mobile and desktop interfaces, ensuring ease of use for users.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate task completion time when filtering tasks by status
phase2_test_cases.description: Measure the time it takes for a user to filter tasks by different statuses and ensure that this process is efficient and does not cause delays in productivity.
preconditions: User has multiple tasks with various statuses
Task management interface is fully functional
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the application and navigate to the Task Management page
Step 2: Select a status filter option (e.g., 'Pending') from the dropdown or checkbox list
Step 3: Record the time before and after selecting the filter to measure how long it takes for tasks to be filtered by the selected status
Step 4: Repeat steps 2-3 with different status options such as 'In Progress' and 'Completed'
Step 5: Ensure that the task filtering process does not exceed a maximum time limit of 2 seconds on both mobile and desktop interfaces
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system filters tasks by status within 2 seconds, ensuring an efficient user experience without delays.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure intuitive navigation and error message clarity for task status filtering
phase2_test_cases.description: Test that navigating to the task status filter is straightforward, and any errors encountered during this process are clearly communicated.
preconditions: User has access to task management features
Task management interface includes error handling
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Management page
Step 2: Attempt to apply a status filter that is not available or incorrectly configured (e.g., an invalid status)
Step 3: Verify that an appropriate and clear error message is displayed indicating why the filter could not be applied
Step 4: Check if the system provides guidance on how to correct the issue or navigate back to a valid state
Step 5: Ensure that navigating to the task status filter from different sections of the application (e.g., dashboard, notifications) is intuitive and does not require complex navigation
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system displays clear error messages when attempting to apply an invalid or unavailable status filter, and provides guidance for correction. Navigation to task status filters from various sections of the application is straightforward.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status on iOS and Android devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that users can filter tasks based on their statuses (all, pending, completed) consistently across iOS and Android platforms.
preconditions: Multiple tasks with different statuses exist
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task management app on an iOS device
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Tasks' section where all tasks are listed
Step 3: Tap the filter button and select 'Pending'
Step 4: Verify that only pending tasks are displayed with correct status icons
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-4 on an Android device, ensuring consistent behavior
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task list should display only pending tasks with correct status icons and the count of displayed tasks should be exactly 5.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - Filtering Tasks by Status

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status on different screen sizes and resolutions
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that filtering tasks based on their statuses works correctly across various screen sizes and resolutions.
preconditions: Multiple tasks with different statuses exist
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task management app on a device with a small screen (e.g., iPhone SE)
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Tasks' section and apply status filter
Step 3: Verify that all UI elements are visible and functional without overlap or truncation
Step 4: Repeat steps 1-3 on a device with medium screen size (e.g., iPhone 8)
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-3 on a large screen device (e.g., iPad Pro)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task list should display all tasks with correct status icons and UI elements should be properly adjusted to fit the screen size without any overlap or truncation issues.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - Filtering Tasks by Status

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status on different browsers and network types
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that filtering tasks based on their statuses functions as expected across various web browsers and network conditions.
preconditions: Multiple tasks with different statuses exist
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task management app's web version in Chrome browser
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Tasks' section and apply status filter for pending tasks
Step 3: Verify that only pending tasks are displayed correctly within 2 seconds
Step 4: Repeat steps 1-3 on Firefox browser with a different set of tasks
Step 5: Test under varying network conditions (WiFi, 4G, 5G) to ensure consistent performance
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task list should display only pending tasks with correct status icons within 2 seconds regardless of the browser or network type used.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - Filtering Tasks by Status

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status 'completed'
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the API correctly filters tasks based on the 'completed' status.
preconditions: User is authenticated with a valid JWT token
Multiple task entries exist in the database
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/tasks?status=completed with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 3: Check response body for tasks where 'completed' field is true
Step 4: Ensure no task in the response has a 'completed' field set to false
Step 5: Confirm that each task includes fields such as 'id', 'title', and 'createdAt'
Step 6: Verify that the number of tasks returned does not exceed the maximum limit specified (e.g., 100)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API returns a list of completed tasks with each task having 'id', 'title', and 'createdAt' fields, and the total number of returned tasks does not exceed 100.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Task Filtering

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status 'incomplete'
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the API correctly filters tasks based on the 'incomplete' status.
preconditions: User is authenticated with a valid JWT token
Multiple task entries exist in the database
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/tasks?status=incomplete with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 3: Check response body for tasks where 'completed' field is false
Step 4: Ensure no task in the response has a 'completed' field set to true
Step 5: Confirm that each task includes fields such as 'id', 'title', and 'createdAt'
Step 6: Verify that the number of tasks returned does not exceed the maximum limit specified (e.g., 100)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API returns a list of incomplete tasks with each task having 'id', 'title', and 'createdAt' fields, and the total number of returned tasks does not exceed 100.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Task Filtering

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status 'all'
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the API correctly returns all tasks when no filter is applied.
preconditions: User is authenticated with a valid JWT token
Multiple task entries exist in the database
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/tasks without any status parameter with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 3: Check response body for all tasks regardless of 'completed' field value
Step 4: Confirm that each task includes fields such as 'id', 'title', and 'createdAt'
Step 5: Ensure the number of tasks returned does not exceed the maximum limit specified (e.g., 100)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API returns a list of all tasks with each task having 'id', 'title', and 'createdAt' fields, and the total number of returned tasks does not exceed 100.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Task Filtering

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify CRUD operations for task status filtering
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks can be created, read, updated, and deleted while maintaining data integrity in the context of status filtering.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid credentials
Multiple tasks exist with various statuses
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "New Task", "status": "pending"}
Step 2: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 3: Use the task ID from Step 1 to send GET request to /api/tasks/{task_id} with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify response body contains the newly created task with correct title and status
Step 5: Send PATCH request to /api/tasks/{task_id} with body {"status": "completed"}
Step 6: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned and task status updated in GET /api/tasks/{task_id} response
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The newly created task with title 'New Task' should have its status correctly updated to 'completed' upon PATCH request, verified by GET response.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate mandatory and optional fields during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that creating a new task with required fields (e.g., title) and without optional fields does not violate data integrity rules.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Mandatory Title", "description": null}
Step 2: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 3: Use the task ID from Step 1 to send GET request to /api/tasks/{task_id} with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify response body contains the newly created task with title 'Mandatory Title' and null description
Step 5: Attempt to create another task without a title using POST /api/tasks with body {"description": "Optional Description"}
Step 6: Verify HTTP 400 status code returned due to missing required field
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: A task with a title but no description should be successfully created, while attempting to create a task without a title must result in an HTTP 400 error due to missing required field.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure data type constraints for task status filtering
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system enforces correct data types when filtering tasks by their statuses.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Task for Data Type Test", "status": "pending"}
Step 2: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 3: Use the task ID from Step 1 to send GET request to /api/tasks/{task_id} with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify response body contains the newly created task with correct title and status 'pending'
Step 5: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Invalid Status Test", "status": 123}
Step 6: Verify HTTP 400 status code returned due to invalid data type for 'status' field
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: A task with a title and valid status should be successfully created, while attempting to create a task with an invalid data type for the 'status' field must result in an HTTP 400 error.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network interruption handling during task filtering by status
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the application's ability to handle network interruptions while a user is attempting to filter tasks by their status.
test_steps: Step 1: User navigates to the task management page and initiates a request to filter tasks by 'In Progress' status
Step 2: Simulate network interruption immediately after initiating the filtering action but before receiving any response from the server
Step 3: After network recovery, user retries the filtering action for 'In Progress' status
Step 4: Verify that all previously filtered tasks by 'In Progress' status are displayed correctly upon retrying
Step 5: Ensure no new or duplicate tasks appear in the results after network recovery and retry
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon successful network reconnection, all tasks filtered by 'In Progress' status should be displayed correctly without any new or duplicate entries.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Network Interruption Handling

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App crash recovery after filtering tasks by status
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the application can recover from a crash and retain the user's task filter settings upon restart.
test_steps: Step 1: User navigates to the task management page and filters tasks by 'Completed' status
Step 2: Simulate app crash immediately after filtering action is completed but before user interaction resumes
Step 3: Restart the application from a cold start
Step 4: Verify that the last applied filter ('Completed') is automatically selected upon restart
Step 5: Confirm that all tasks filtered by 'Completed' status are displayed correctly without any loss or duplication
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After the app crashes and restarts, the previously applied filter ('Completed') should be automatically selected and all corresponding tasks should be displayed correctly.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - App Crash Recovery

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Data persistence across crashes after filtering by status
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the application maintains task filter settings and data integrity even if it crashes multiple times during a session.
test_steps: Step 1: User filters tasks by 'Pending' status on the task management page
Step 2: Simulate app crash immediately after filtering action is completed but before user interaction resumes
Step 3: Restart the application and verify that the filter ('Pending') is still applied
Step 4: Repeat steps 2-3 two more times to simulate multiple crashes during a single session
Step 5: Confirm that upon each restart, tasks filtered by 'Pending' status are displayed correctly without any loss or duplication
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After multiple crashes during a session, the application should persistently apply the filter ('Pending') and display all corresponding tasks accurately upon each restart.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Data Persistence Across Crashes

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status 'all' when no tasks exist
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system correctly displays an empty state message when filtering tasks by status 'all' and there are no tasks in the database.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Ensure that no tasks are present in the system
Step 3: Click on the 'Filter by Status' dropdown menu and select 'all'
Step 4: Verify that an empty state message is displayed indicating there are no tasks available
Step 5: Confirm that clicking on any navigation links or buttons does not result in task display
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system displays an empty state message such as 'No tasks found' when filtering by status 'all' and there are no tasks available.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status 'completed' when all tasks are active
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system correctly handles a scenario where there are no completed tasks and filters them out.
preconditions: Tasks exist but none are marked as completed
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Confirm that all existing tasks are active (not completed)
Step 3: Click on the 'Filter by Status' dropdown menu and select 'completed'
Step 4: Verify that an empty state message is displayed indicating there are no completed tasks available
Step 5: Ensure that clicking any navigation links or buttons does not result in task display
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system displays an empty state message such as 'No completed tasks found' when filtering by status 'completed' and there are no completed tasks available.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by status 'all' with maximum task limit reached
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system correctly handles displaying up to the maximum number of tasks (100) when filtering by status 'all'.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Confirm that exactly 100 tasks are present in the system
Step 3: Click on the 'Filter by Status' dropdown menu and select 'all'
Step 4: Verify that all 100 tasks are displayed without pagination or truncation issues
Step 5: Ensure that attempting to add a new task results in an alert message indicating the maximum limit has been reached
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system displays all 100 tasks when filtering by status 'all' and shows an alert message like 'Maximum task limit reached' upon attempting to add a new task.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks by invalid status value
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that attempting to filter tasks using an invalid status value results in a clear error message.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Click on the 'Filter by Status' dropdown menu
Step 3: Select an invalid status value (e.g., 'invalid_status') from the dropdown or manually enter it in the filter input field
Step 4: Observe that no tasks are displayed and a clear error message is shown indicating the invalid status selection
Step 5: Click on the 'Clear Filter' button to reset the filters and verify that all tasks are visible again
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the selected status is invalid, no tasks should be displayed, and clicking 'Clear Filter' should restore all tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks with empty status value
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that filtering tasks with an empty status value does not return any results and provides a clear feedback message.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Click on the 'Filter by Status' dropdown menu
Step 3: Select an empty status value or leave the filter input field blank and apply the filter
Step 4: Verify that no tasks are displayed and a message is shown indicating that there are no results for the selected criteria
Step 5: Click on the 'Clear Filter' button to reset the filters and ensure all tasks are visible again
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a message indicating that there are no results for the selected criteria, and clicking 'Clear Filter' should restore all tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Filter tasks with non-existent status value
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that attempting to filter tasks using a non-existent status value results in an appropriate error message.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Click on the 'Filter by Status' dropdown menu
Step 3: Select a non-existent status value (e.g., 'pending') from the dropdown or manually enter it in the filter input field
Step 4: Verify that no tasks are displayed and an error message is shown indicating that the selected status does not exist
Step 5: Click on the 'Clear Filter' button to reset the filters and ensure all tasks are visible again
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the selected status does not exist, no tasks should be displayed, and clicking 'Clear Filter' should restore all tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify performance of creating and retrieving a task in MySQL for logged-in user
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can efficiently create and retrieve a task stored in MySQL, visible only to the logged-in user.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
MySQL database is up and running
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"title": "Prepare for meeting", "description": "Review presentation slides and notes", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Send GET request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 5: Verify response body contains the newly created task with auto-generated ID and title "Prepare for meeting"
Step 6: Ensure no other tasks are present in the response
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should create a new task and immediately retrieve it with an HTTP status code of 200, containing the exact title 'Prepare for meeting' and no other tasks in the response.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - Task Creation and Retrieval

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify performance of creating multiple tasks and retrieving them within a time limit
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can handle creation and retrieval of up to 100 tasks efficiently, visible only to the logged-in user.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
MySQL database is up and running
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks for each task from 1 to 100 with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body for each task: {"title": "Task #n", "description": "Description of Task #n", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned for all tasks
Step 4: Send GET request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 5: Measure the time taken to retrieve all 100 tasks and ensure it is within 2 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should create up to 100 tasks, each with a unique title 'Task #n', and retrieve all of them within 2 seconds when requested.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - Bulk Task Creation and Retrieval

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify performance impact on system after deleting a task
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the deletion of a single task has minimal performance impact, maintaining visibility only to the logged-in user.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
MySQL database contains at least one task
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Identify a specific task ID from the response
Step 3: Send DELETE request to /api/tasks/{task_id} with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned for deletion
Step 5: Send GET request again to /api/tasks and verify the task is no longer present
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should delete a specific task identified by its ID, returning an HTTP status code of 200 upon deletion and ensuring the task is not present in subsequent GET requests.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify that a user's data is not visible to other users in MySQL
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks stored in the database are only accessible by their respective owners and not visible to other logged-in users.
preconditions: User A has created at least one task
User B is another registered user with no shared tasks
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as User A using a valid JWT token
Step 2: Navigate to the 'My Tasks' page and verify that User A's tasks are listed
Step 3: Log out of User A's account and log in as User B with a different valid JWT token
Step 4: Attempt to access User A's tasks by navigating directly to their task IDs via URL manipulation
Step 5: Verify that the server responds with HTTP status code 403 Forbidden for each attempt to access User A's tasks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The server must return HTTP status code 403 Forbidden when User B attempts to access any of User A's tasks, ensuring data isolation and security.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify that a user cannot modify another user's task in MySQL
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks stored in the database can only be modified by their respective owners and not by other users.
preconditions: User A has created at least one task
User B is another registered user with no shared tasks
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as User A using a valid JWT token
Step 2: Navigate to the 'My Tasks' page and verify that User A's tasks are listed
Step 3: Log out of User A's account and log in as User B with a different valid JWT token
Step 4: Attempt to modify one of User A's tasks by sending a PUT request to /api/tasks/{task_id} with updated task details
Step 5: Verify that the server responds with HTTP status code 403 Forbidden for each attempt to modify User A's tasks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The server must return HTTP status code 403 Forbidden when User B attempts to modify any of User A's tasks, ensuring data integrity and security.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify that a user cannot delete another user's task in MySQL
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks stored in the database can only be deleted by their respective owners and not by other users.
preconditions: User A has created at least one task
User B is another registered user with no shared tasks
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as User A using a valid JWT token
Step 2: Navigate to the 'My Tasks' page and verify that User A's tasks are listed
Step 3: Log out of User A's account and log in as User B with a different valid JWT token
Step 4: Attempt to delete one of User A's tasks by sending a DELETE request to /api/tasks/{task_id}
Step 5: Verify that the server responds with HTTP status code 403 Forbidden for each attempt to delete User A's tasks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The server must return HTTP status code 403 Forbidden when User B attempts to delete any of User A's tasks, ensuring data integrity and security.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system persistence of tasks in MySQL and visibility to logged-in user
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that a task created by a user is stored persistently in the database and visible only to the same user upon login.
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the system using a valid user account
Step 2: Navigate to the task creation page and click on 'Add Task'
Step 3: Enter a new task title (e.g., 'Complete project report') in the designated field and ensure it is saved successfully
Step 4: Log out of the system and log back in with another user account
Step 5: Navigate to the task list page and verify that the previously created task does not appear for this different user
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The newly added task 'Complete project report' should only be visible to the user who created it (e.g., alice@example.com) and not appear in another user's task list (e.g., bob@example.com).

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate error message clarity when attempting to view another user's task
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that a clear and informative error message is displayed when a logged-in user tries to access tasks belonging to another user.
preconditions: Two separate user accounts with valid credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the system using User A's account
Step 2: Create a new task and ensure it is saved successfully
Step 3: Log out of User A's account and log in as User B
Step 4: Attempt to navigate directly to the URL for User A's task (e.g., /tasks/123)
Step 5: Verify that a clear error message is displayed stating 'Access denied. This task does not belong to you.'
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: When User B attempts to access a task belonging to User A, an error message 'Access denied. This task does not belong to you.' should be displayed prominently on the screen.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Evaluate navigation intuitiveness for task visibility across different devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the navigation to view tasks is intuitive and consistent across desktop and mobile interfaces.
preconditions: Access to both desktop and mobile versions of the application
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the system using a valid user account from a desktop browser
Step 2: Navigate through the main navigation menu to find 'My Tasks' or equivalent link
Step 3: Verify that all tasks are listed and accessible without any additional clicks or steps
Step 4: Log out of the system and log back in using a mobile device's browser
Step 5: Navigate through the mobile app menu to find 'My Tasks' or equivalent link, ensuring it is easily discoverable
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: On both desktop and mobile interfaces, the user should be able to navigate directly from the main menu to their task list without encountering any confusing steps or additional clicks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system persistence in MySQL and visibility on iOS devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks persisted in MySQL are visible only to the logged-in user on an iPhone.
preconditions: User is logged into the application
Task data has been saved to MySQL
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as User A and create a new task titled 'Buy groceries'
Step 2: Verify that the newly created task appears on the Task List page
Step 3: Log out of the application and log back in as User B
Step 4: Navigate to the Task List page and verify that no tasks are visible for User B
Step 5: Log back in as User A and navigate to the Task List page, verifying that 'Buy groceries' is still present
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task titled 'Buy groceries', created by User A, should be visible only when logged in as User A and not visible to other users such as User B.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system persistence in MySQL and visibility on Android devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks persisted in MySQL are visible only to the logged-in user on an Android device.
preconditions: User is logged into the application
Task data has been saved to MySQL
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as User C and create a new task titled 'Read book'
Step 2: Verify that the newly created task appears on the Task List page
Step 3: Log out of the application and log back in as User D
Step 4: Navigate to the Task List page and verify that no tasks are visible for User D
Step 5: Log back in as User C and navigate to the Task List page, verifying that 'Read book' is still present
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task titled 'Read book', created by User C, should be visible only when logged in as User C and not visible to other users such as User D.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system persistence in MySQL and visibility across different screen sizes on web-based application
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks persisted in MySQL are visible only to the logged-in user regardless of the screen size used.
preconditions: User is logged into the application
Task data has been saved to MySQL
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as User E and create a new task titled 'Write report'
Step 2: Verify that the newly created task appears on the Task List page
Step 3: Resize the browser window to simulate different screen sizes (e.g., mobile, tablet, desktop)
Step 4: For each screen size, verify that the task list displays correctly and 'Write report' is visible only when logged in as User E
Step 5: Log out of the application and log back in as User F
Step 6: Verify that no tasks are visible for User F across all tested screen sizes
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task titled 'Write report', created by User E, should be visible only when logged in as User E and not visible to other users such as User F across all tested screen sizes.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify that a new task is persisted in MySQL and visible only to the logged-in user
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that when a new task is created, it is stored in the database and can be retrieved by the same user but not others.
preconditions: User A has an active session with JWT token
User B does not have any sessions
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <user_a_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Task for User A", "description": "Description of task for user a", "status": false}
Step 2: Verify HTTP status code is 201 (Created)
Step 3: Send GET request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <user_a_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify the newly created task appears in the response and has a unique ID
Step 5: Send GET request to /api/tasks without any authorization headers or with User B's token
Step 6: Verify HTTP status code is 401 (Unauthorized) for unauthenticated requests
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The new task should be successfully created and stored in the database, visible only to the authenticated user who created it. Unauthorized access attempts from other users or without authentication must return HTTP 401 status code.

test_data.description: Description of task for user a

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure task visibility is restricted to the user who created it
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that a logged-in user can only see tasks they have created and not those of other users.
preconditions: User A has an active session with JWT token
User B has an active session with JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: User A creates a task via POST /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <user_a_jwt_token>
Step 2: Verify HTTP status code is 201 (Created)
Step 3: User B creates a different task via POST /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <user_b_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify HTTP status code is 201 (Created) for User B's request
Step 5: User A retrieves tasks via GET /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <user_a_jwt_token>
Step 6: Verify the response contains only the task created by User A and not User B's task
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: User A should only see the tasks they have created in their GET /api/tasks response, and not those created by other users such as User B.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate task persistence in MySQL upon creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that a newly created task is immediately stored and retrievable from the database.
preconditions: User has an active session with JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <user_jwt_token> and body {"title": "New Task", "description": "Task description", "status": false}
Step 2: Verify HTTP status code is 201 (Created)
Step 3: Immediately send GET request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <user_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify the newly created task appears in the response
Step 5: Check MySQL database for the presence of the new task record
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: A newly created task should be immediately stored in the MySQL database and visible to the user who created it upon retrieval.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify CRUD operations for task persistence in MySQL
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks created, read, updated, and deleted by a logged-in user are correctly persisted in the database and visible only to that specific user.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
MySQL server is running and accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"title": "Task Title", "description": "Task Description", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Send GET request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 5: Ensure the newly created task is present in the response and matches the POSTed data
Step 6: Update the task using PUT request to /api/tasks/<task_id> with updated title and description, verify HTTP 200 status code
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task should be successfully created, retrieved with correct details, and updated in the database. The response from GET request must include exactly one task matching the POSTed data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate foreign key relationships and transaction integrity for tasks
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task creation process respects foreign key constraints with user IDs, and transactions are handled correctly to maintain data consistency.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
MySQL server is running and accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"title": "Task Title", "description": "Task Description", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Attempt to delete the user associated with the task using DELETE /api/users/<user_id>
Step 5: Expect a foreign key constraint violation error indicating that tasks are still linked to this user
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Deleting the user should fail with an IntegrityError due to existing foreign key constraints. The error message must indicate that tasks are still linked to this user.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Check mandatory vs optional fields and data type constraints for task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the title field is mandatory, description is optional, and all fields adhere to their specified data types.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
MySQL server is running and accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body without title field: {"description": "Task Description", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 400 status code returned
Step 4: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 5: Include request body with invalid data types: {"title": 123, "description": [], "completed": "true"}
Step 6: Verify HTTP 400 status code returned
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Creating a task without the title field should return an HTTP 400 status code with an error message indicating that the title is missing. Attempting to create a task with invalid data types for title and description fields should also result in an HTTP 400 status code.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During Data Persistence
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can handle network interruptions during data persistence and recover correctly upon reconnection.
preconditions: System has created a new task with title 'Test Task'
test_steps: Step 1: Create a new task titled 'Test Task' via API POST request to /api/tasks
Step 2: Simulate network interruption by disconnecting the internet connection
Step 3: Attempt to retrieve the newly created task via GET request to /api/tasks/{task_id}
Step 4: Re-establish the network connection and retry retrieving the task
Step 5: Verify that the 'Test Task' is successfully retrieved from the server
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should persist the 'Test Task' locally and ensure it is visible to the logged-in user upon re-establishing network connectivity.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery and Data Integrity
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the application can recover from a crash without losing data persistence.
preconditions: User has created a task titled 'Test Task'
test_steps: Step 1: Create a new task titled 'Test Task' via API POST request to /api/tasks
Step 2: Force the application to crash (e.g., by terminating the process)
Step 3: Restart the application and log back in with the same credentials
Step 4: Retrieve all tasks from the server using GET request to /api/tasks
Step 5: Verify that the 'Test Task' is present in the retrieved list of tasks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon restarting and logging back into the application, the system should ensure that all previously created tasks, including 'Test Task', are visible to the user.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Session Timeout Handling and Data Visibility
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that session timeouts do not result in data loss or incorrect visibility of tasks.
preconditions: User has created a task titled 'Test Task'
test_steps: Step 1: Create a new task titled 'Test Task' via API POST request to /api/tasks
Step 2: Wait until the session times out (e.g., after 30 minutes of inactivity)
Step 3: Log back into the application with the same credentials
Step 4: Retrieve all tasks from the server using GET request to /api/tasks
Step 5: Verify that the 'Test Task' is present and visible upon re-login
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After a session timeout, when the user logs back in, all previously created tasks, including 'Test Task', should be correctly displayed and accessible.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify that a task is visible only to the logged-in user in MySQL
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks created by one user are not visible to another user and are stored correctly in MySQL.
preconditions: User A logs into the system
User B logs into the system
test_steps: Step 1: User A creates a new task titled 'Task for User A' via the 'Add Task' page
Step 2: Verify that the task is stored in MySQL with user_id of User A using SQL query
Step 3: User B navigates to their 'My Tasks' page and verifies no tasks are listed
Step 4: User A logs out and then logs back in, verifying that 'Task for User A' appears on the 'My Tasks' page
Step 5: Verify that attempting to access Task for User A's ID via User B's account results in a 'Not Found' error
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task 'Task for User A' is stored in MySQL with user_id 1234567890 and not visible to any other users, ensuring data privacy.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify that a task is stored with the correct user ID in MySQL upon creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that when a new task is created, it is associated with the logged-in user's ID and not any other.
preconditions: User A logs into the system
test_steps: Step 1: User A creates a new task titled 'Task for User A' via the 'Add Task' page
