Step 2: Verify that the newly created task is stored in MySQL with user_id of User A using SQL query
Step 3: Attempt to create another task as User B and verify it fails due to incorrect authentication
Step 4: Log out User A and log in as User B, then attempt to view 'Task for User A' via the 'My Tasks' page
Step 5: Verify that attempting to edit or delete Task for User A from User B's account results in a 'Not Found' error
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task 'Task for User A' is stored in MySQL with user_id 1234567890 and not accessible or editable by any other users, ensuring data integrity.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify that a task is deleted from MySQL and not visible to any other user upon deletion by the owner
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that when a task is deleted, it is removed from MySQL and does not appear in any other user's 'My Tasks' page.
preconditions: User A logs into the system
User B logs into the system
test_steps: Step 1: User A creates a new task titled 'Task for User A' via the 'Add Task' page
Step 2: Verify that the newly created task is stored in MySQL with user_id of User A using SQL query
Step 3: User A deletes the task from their 'My Tasks' page
Step 4: Verify that the task has been deleted from MySQL using SQL query
Step 5: User B navigates to their 'My Tasks' page and verifies no tasks are listed
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task 'Task for User A' is successfully deleted from MySQL and does not appear in any other user's 'My Tasks' page, ensuring data privacy.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle MySQL connection failure during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system handles a failed database connection gracefully when attempting to create a new task.
preconditions: User is logged in and has valid session token
Database server is running but temporarily unavailable
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with a valid JWT token
Step 2: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 3: Include request body: {"title": "New Task", "description": "Task description", "status": "pending"}
Step 4: Temporarily shut down the MySQL database server
Step 5: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 500 with an appropriate error message indicating a connection failure
Step 6: Ensure no new task is created in the database
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system returns an HTTP status code of 500 and a JSON response with an error message stating 'Database connection failed'. The task should not be created in the database.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle duplicate task creation for logged-in user
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system prevents a logged-in user from creating multiple tasks with identical titles.
preconditions: User is logged in and has valid session token
A task already exists with the same title
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with a valid JWT token
Step 2: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 3: Include request body: {"title": "Existing Task", "description": "Task description", "status": "pending"}
Step 4: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 409 and a JSON response with an error message indicating 'Duplicate task title'
Step 5: Ensure no duplicate entry is created in the database for this user
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system returns a HTTP status code of 409 and a JSON response with an error message stating 'Task title already exists'. The duplicate task should not be created in the database.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle invalid user input during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system validates and rejects tasks created with missing or incorrect data.
preconditions: User is logged in and has valid session token
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with a valid JWT token
Step 2: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 3: Include request body without the 'title' field: {"description": "Task description", "status": "pending"}
Step 4: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 400 and a JSON response with an error message indicating missing required fields
Step 5: Ensure no task is created in the database for this user
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system returns an HTTP status code of 400 and a JSON response with an error message stating 'Missing required field: title'. The task should not be created in the database.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test: Hashing User Data Using Passport
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the performance of user data hashing using passport when a large number of users log in simultaneously.
preconditions: Ensure system is running and all dependencies are met
Create 10,000 test user accounts with unique credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate concurrent login attempts for 5,000 users using a load testing tool
Step 2: Monitor the response time of each login request and ensure it does not exceed 2 seconds per request
Step 3: Verify that all login requests return HTTP status code 200 (OK) indicating successful authentication
Step 4: Check if the system remains responsive with no more than a 5% increase in response time during peak load
Step 5: Confirm that user sessions are correctly managed and maintained after login, ensuring users can access their profiles without additional authentication
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle up to 5,000 concurrent login attempts with an average response time of less than 2 seconds per request and maintain a maximum increase in overall response time by no more than 5%.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: System ensure that the system be hashed using passport

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test: Hashing User Data Under High Load
phase2_test_cases.description: Evaluate the performance of user data hashing under high load conditions to ensure stability and reliability.
preconditions: Ensure system is running and all dependencies are met
Create 10,000 test user accounts with unique credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate concurrent login attempts for 8,000 users using a load testing tool
Step 2: Monitor the response time of each login request and ensure it does not exceed 3 seconds per request
Step 3: Verify that all login requests return HTTP status code 200 (OK) indicating successful authentication
Step 4: Check if the system remains responsive with no more than a 10% increase in response time during peak load
Step 5: Confirm that user sessions are correctly managed and maintained after login, ensuring users can access their profiles without additional authentication
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle up to 8,000 concurrent login attempts with an average response time of less than 3 seconds per request and maintain a maximum increase in overall response time by no more than 10%.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: System ensure that the system be hashed using passport

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test: Hashing User Data with Increased Concurrent Users
phase2_test_cases.description: Test the performance of user data hashing when the number of concurrent users increases to a very high level.
preconditions: Ensure system is running and all dependencies are met
Create 10,000 test user accounts with unique credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate concurrent login attempts for 9,500 users using a load testing tool
Step 2: Monitor the response time of each login request and ensure it does not exceed 4 seconds per request
Step 3: Verify that all login requests return HTTP status code 200 (OK) indicating successful authentication
Step 4: Check if the system remains responsive with no more than a 15% increase in response time during peak load
Step 5: Confirm that user sessions are correctly managed and maintained after login, ensuring users can access their profiles without additional authentication
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle up to 9,500 concurrent login attempts with an average response time of less than 4 seconds per request and maintain a maximum increase in overall response time by no more than 15%.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: System ensure that the system be hashed using passport

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure password hashing using bcrypt algorithm
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system uses bcrypt for hashing passwords and does not use weak or deprecated algorithms like MD5, SHA-1.
test_steps: Step 1: Register a new user with a password of 'TestPassword123!' through the system's registration page
Step 2: Retrieve the hashed password from the database for the newly registered user
Step 3: Verify that the retrieved hash is in bcrypt format, starting with '$2b$'
Step 4: Attempt to use a known weak hashing algorithm (e.g., MD5) on 'TestPassword123!' and compare it against the stored hash
Step 5: Confirm that the weakly hashed password does not match the stored bcrypt hash
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must store passwords using bcrypt hashing algorithm, and a comparison with a non-bcrypt hash should fail to match the stored password.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent brute force attacks on login attempts
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system implements a mechanism to prevent brute force attacks by locking accounts or temporarily blocking IP addresses after multiple failed login attempts.
preconditions: User account exists with known credentials
test_steps: Step 1: Attempt to log in using incorrect passwords for an existing user account five consecutive times
Step 2: Check if the system locks or temporarily disables the user's account after these failed attempts
Step 3: Try logging into another user account from a different IP address and repeat step 1
Step 4: Verify that the system blocks the IP address used for multiple failed login attempts
Step 5: Wait until the lockout period expires, then attempt to log in with correct credentials
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After five consecutive failed login attempts, the system must either lock the user's account or block the IP address for at least 10 minutes before allowing another attempt.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: User Authentication - Security Measures Against Brute Force Attacks

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate password strength requirements during registration
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system enforces strong password policies such as minimum length, complexity (uppercase/lowercase/numbers/special characters), and disallows common weak passwords.
test_steps: Step 1: Attempt to register a new account with the password 'password'
Step 2: Check if the system rejects this password due to being too simple or common
Step 3: Try registering another account with a weak password like '123456'
Step 4: Verify that the system does not allow passwords shorter than 8 characters, lacking complexity (e.g., missing uppercase letters)
Step 5: Attempt to register an account using a strong password meeting all criteria and confirm successful registration
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must reject weak passwords and enforce a minimum length of 8 characters with at least one uppercase letter, lowercase letter, number, and special character.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify user can hash password using passport during registration
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system allows users to register and securely hash their passwords using passport.
preconditions: User has entered all required fields
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the registration page via the 'Sign Up' button
Step 2: Enter a valid email address in the 'Email' field
Step 3: Enter a strong password in the 'Password' field and confirm it in the 'Confirm Password' field
Step 4: Click on the 'Register' button to submit the registration form
Step 5: Verify that an account creation confirmation message is displayed
Step 6: Check if the user can log in with the newly created credentials
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: User registration completes successfully, and a confirmation message is displayed indicating that the password has been securely hashed using passport.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Registration Process

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify error message clarity when user enters an invalid password during registration
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system displays clear and informative error messages when a user attempts to register with an invalid password.
preconditions: User has entered all required fields except for password
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the registration page via the 'Sign Up' button
Step 2: Enter a valid email address in the 'Email' field
Step 3: Enter an invalid password (e.g., too short) in the 'Password' field and confirm it in the 'Confirm Password' field
Step 4: Click on the 'Register' button to submit the registration form
Step 5: Verify that a clear error message is displayed indicating why the password is invalid
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: A specific and informative error message is displayed, such as 'Password must be at least 8 characters long', preventing the user from proceeding with an insecure password.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Registration Process

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify mobile and desktop consistency in displaying hashed password confirmation message
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system consistently displays a confirmation message about password hashing across both mobile and desktop platforms.
preconditions: User has entered all required fields
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the registration page via the 'Sign Up' button
Step 2: Enter a valid email address in the 'Email' field
Step 3: Enter a strong password in the 'Password' field and confirm it in the 'Confirm Password' field
Step 4: Click on the 'Register' button to submit the registration form
Step 5: Verify that an account creation confirmation message is displayed on both mobile and desktop platforms
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system displays a consistent confirmation message indicating successful registration and secure password hashing, regardless of whether the user is on a mobile or desktop device.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Registration Process

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system hashing using passport works on iOS and Android devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system ensures user data is hashed correctly when signing up or logging in, specifically focusing on differences between iOS and Android platforms.
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the application on an iPhone with iOS version 15.0
Step 2: Navigate to the login screen and enter a registered user's email address and password
Step 3: Tap the 'Login' button and observe that the system redirects the user to the dashboard after successful authentication
Step 4: Check the server logs or use network monitoring tools to confirm that the password was hashed before being sent to the backend
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-4 on an Android device with version 12.0, ensuring identical behavior and data handling
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should successfully authenticate the user after hashing their password on both iOS (version 15.0) and Android (version 12.0) devices, with no visible changes to the UI or user experience.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system hashing using passport on different screen sizes and resolutions
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the application's user data handling mechanism, specifically password hashing, functions correctly across various screen sizes and resolutions.
test_steps: Step 1: Set up an iPhone with a resolution of 375x812 (iPhone X)
Step 2: Sign in using the login credentials 'user@example.com' and 'SecurePassword123!'
Step 3: Change device settings to emulate a smaller screen size, such as 320x480 (iPhone SE)
Step 4: Repeat sign-in process on this new screen configuration
Step 5: Use an Android tablet with resolution 1920x1200 and repeat the login process
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should authenticate users seamlessly across different screen sizes (iPhone X, iPhone SE) and resolutions (Android tablet 1920x1200), ensuring password hashing occurs without any UI or performance issues.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate system hashing using passport on various network types (WiFi, 4G, 5G)
phase2_test_cases.description: Test the application's password hashing functionality under different network conditions to ensure reliability and performance.
preconditions: Device can switch between WiFi, 4G, and 5G networks
test_steps: Step 1: Connect an Android device with version 12.0 to a stable WiFi network
Step 2: Sign in using 'user@example.com' and 'SecurePassword123!'
Step 3: Disconnect from WiFi and connect to a 4G mobile data network, then sign in again
Step 4: Switch the device's network connection to 5G (if available) and repeat login process
Step 5: Monitor server logs or use network analysis tools to confirm password hashing occurs on all tested networks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should authenticate users and hash passwords successfully across WiFi, 4G, and 5G network types without any delays or errors in the login process.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system hashes using passport for user authentication
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system correctly hashes passwords and uses passport for authentication when a new user is created.
preconditions: A valid API endpoint for creating users
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/users with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "john_doe", "password": "secretpassword"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains user ID and username but no password field
Step 5: Attempt to retrieve the same user via GET /api/users/{user_id} without a hashed password in the response
Step 6: Confirm that passport middleware is correctly configured by attempting login with correct credentials
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return a HTTP 201 status code and the user details without the password field, confirming that passwords are hashed and passport is correctly configured.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify rate limiting on user creation endpoint
phase2_test_cases.description: Check that the system enforces a rate limit of 5 requests per minute for creating new users.
preconditions: Rate limiting middleware installed and configured
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/users with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "alice", "password": "pass123"}
Step 3: Repeat step 1 four more times within a minute
Step 4: Send another POST request to /api/users after the rate limit window has passed
Step 5: Verify that all requests except for the last one return HTTP 429 status code
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should enforce a rate limit of 5 requests per minute, returning an HTTP 429 status code for the first four attempts within one minute and allowing the fifth request to succeed.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Rate Limiting on User Creation Endpoint

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate response time for user authentication endpoint
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system responds to a POST request to /api/auth within 2 seconds.
preconditions: API server is running and accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/auth with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "jane", "password": "userpass"}
Step 3: Measure the time taken for the server to respond
Step 4: Verify that the HTTP status code returned is 200 OK
Step 5: Confirm that the response time does not exceed 2 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should respond to a POST request to /api/auth with an HTTP 200 status code and complete the response within 2 seconds.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Response Time for User Authentication Endpoint

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system integrity after user registration using hashed credentials
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that upon successful user registration, the system correctly hashes and stores user credentials.
preconditions: A valid JWT token is obtained
User registration form is filled with all required fields
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the user registration page in the application

Step 2: Fill out the registration form with a new username and password, ensuring that both are within the specified character limits (e.g., username between 5-30 characters, password at least 8 characters long)
Step 3: Submit the registration form by clicking the 'Register' button
Step 4: Verify that the system returns a success message indicating successful user creation and redirects to the login page
Step 5: Attempt to log in with the newly registered username and password, ensuring that the system correctly hashes the password before comparison
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user is successfully redirected to the login page after registration, and upon attempting to log in with the provided credentials, the system verifies the hashed password against the stored hash value.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate data consistency after creating a new task in Task Management System
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that when a user creates a new task, the system correctly stores and retrieves the task details without any data loss or corruption.
preconditions: User is logged into the application
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the Task Management System with valid credentials
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Create New Task' page and fill out all mandatory fields (e.g., task title, due date)
Step 3: Submit the form by clicking the 'Save' button
Step 4: Verify that the system returns a success message indicating successful task creation
Step 5: Navigate to the 'My Tasks' page and verify that the newly created task appears in the list with all details correctly displayed
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system displays a success message after creating the new task, and upon navigating to the 'My Tasks' page, the newly created task is listed with all details (title: Complete project report, due date: 2023-12-31) correctly shown.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Check data consistency after updating task status in Task Management System
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that when a user updates the status of an existing task, the system correctly reflects this change without any inconsistencies.
preconditions: User is logged into the application
Task list with at least one task
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the Task Management System
Step 2: Navigate to the 'My Tasks' page and locate an existing task that has not been completed yet
Step 3: Click on the task title to open the task details view
Step 4: Change the status of the task from 'Not Started' to 'In Progress'
Step 5: Save the changes by clicking the 'Update Task' button and verify that the system returns a success message
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task status is successfully updated from 'Not Started' to 'In Progress', and upon refreshing the page, the system displays the updated status correctly.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During Task Creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system can handle network interruptions during task creation and recover successfully once connectivity is restored.
preconditions: User logged in with valid JWT token
Task details ready to be created
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Create task", "description": "Test description", "completed": false}
Step 2: Simulate network interruption by disconnecting the device from internet
Step 3: Observe system behavior (expected UI message indicating connection issue)
Step 4: Re-establish network connectivity and retry sending the POST request to /api/tasks
Step 5: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned upon successful task creation
Step 6: Confirm that newly created task appears in GET /api/tasks response
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a user-friendly message indicating network issues and allow the POST request to succeed once connectivity is restored, with the newly created task appearing in the GET response.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery During Task Editing
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that after an app crash, the system can recover and retain all unsaved changes made to a task.
preconditions: User logged in with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Open task editing page for a specific task
Step 2: Make changes to the task title and description without saving
Step 3: Force close the app (e.g., by swiping up on recent apps list)
Step 4: Reopen the app and navigate back to the task editing screen
Step 5: Verify that all unsaved changes made before the crash are still present in the task editing form
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon reopening the app, the system should automatically load and display all unsaved changes made to the task before the crash occurred.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Data Persistence Across Crashes During Task Deletion
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system retains task deletion status even after an app crash.
preconditions: User logged in with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to a specific task's detail page
Step 2: Initiate the process of deleting the task (e.g., by clicking delete button)
Step 3: Force close the app before confirming deletion
Step 4: Reopen the app and navigate back to the task list view
Step 5: Verify that the deleted task is no longer visible in the task list
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After reopening the app, the system should reflect the deletion of the task as if the delete operation had been completed before the crash.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Hashing system ensures correct hashing of user data using passport
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system correctly hashes user data when a new user is created via the API.
preconditions: A valid JWT token for authentication
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/users with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "newuser", "password": "SecurePassword123!"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned indicating successful user creation
Step 4: Query the newly created user's data from /api/users/<user_id>
Step 5: Confirm that the 'hashed_password' field is present and does not match the original password provided in Step 2
Step 6: Ensure that the hashed_password length matches expected hash length for bcrypt (e.g., 60 characters)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should successfully create a new user with the password correctly hashed using bcrypt, and the returned 'hashed_password' field length must be exactly 60 characters.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Hashing system handles empty password input correctly
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system does not allow creation of a user with an empty password and returns appropriate error response.
preconditions: A valid JWT token for authentication
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/users with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "emptyuser", "password": ""}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 400 status code returned indicating bad request
Step 4: Confirm that the response includes an error message stating 'Password cannot be empty'
Step 5: Attempt to create another user with a valid password and verify successful creation
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return an HTTP 400 status code along with an error message stating 'Password cannot be empty' when attempting to create a user with an empty password.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Hashing system handles very long passwords correctly
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can handle and hash extremely long password inputs without failing.
preconditions: A valid JWT token for authentication
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/users with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>

Step 2: Include request body: {"username": "longpassworduser", "password": "AveryVeryLongPasswordThatExceedsNormalLimitsButIsStillValidForTestingPurposesAndShouldBeHandledGracefullyByTheSystemWithoutCrashingOrFailingToHashProperly"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned indicating successful user creation
Step 4: Query the newly created user's data from /api/users/<user_id>
Step 5: Confirm that the 'hashed_password' field is present and does not match the original password provided in Step 2
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should successfully create a new user with the very long password correctly hashed using bcrypt, and the returned 'hashed_password' field length must be exactly 60 characters.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles invalid JWT token for hashing
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system correctly identifies and responds to an invalid JWT token when attempting to hash user data.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid session
System has a hashed password mechanism using passport
test_steps: Step 1: Retrieve a valid JWT token from the user's current session
Step 2: Modify the JWT token by changing one character to make it invalid
Step 3: Send an API request with the modified, invalid JWT token to hash a new password using /api/hash endpoint
Step 4: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized
Step 5: Check the response body for error message 'Invalid Token'
Step 6: Confirm that no hashing operation is performed on the user's data
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must return HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized and an error message 'Invalid Token' in the response body, indicating that no hashing operation is performed on the user's data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles missing JWT token for hashing
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system correctly identifies and responds when a required JWT token is missing during the password hashing process.
preconditions: User session exists but JWT token is not provided
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the application without providing a JWT token
Step 2: Attempt to hash a new password using /api/hash endpoint without including the JWT token in the request headers
Step 3: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized
Step 4: Check the response body for error message 'Missing Token'
Step 5: Confirm that no hashing operation is performed on the user's data
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must return HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized and an error message 'Missing Token' in the response body, indicating that no hashing operation is performed on the user's data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles expired JWT token for hashing
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system correctly identifies and responds to an expired JWT token when attempting to hash user data.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid but expired session
test_steps: Step 1: Retrieve an expired JWT token from the user's current session
Step 2: Send an API request with the expired JWT token to hash a new password using /api/hash endpoint
Step 3: Verify that the system returns HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized
Step 4: Check the response body for error message 'Token has Expired'
Step 5: Confirm that no hashing operation is performed on the user's data
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must return HTTP status code 401 Unauthorized and an error message 'Token has Expired' in the response body, indicating that no hashing operation is performed on the user's data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system responsiveness on mobile devices under high load
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the task management application remains responsive and performs optimally when a large number of users are simultaneously accessing it from mobile devices.
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate 100 concurrent users on the task management application using a load testing tool
Step 2: Navigate to the home page of the application and observe the loading time for initial content rendering
Step 3: Perform CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on tasks and measure response times for each action
Step 4: Check if all UI elements are responsive and interactive without any lag or freezing during high load conditions
Step 5: Monitor the application's performance metrics to ensure no server-side errors or timeouts occur
Step 6: Verify that the system maintains a consistent user experience with smooth transitions and animations
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management application should maintain an average response time of less than 2 seconds for all CRUD operations under a simulated load of 100 concurrent users, with no server-side errors reported.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system responsiveness on desktop devices under high load
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the task management application remains responsive and performs optimally when a large number of users are simultaneously accessing it from desktop browsers.
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate 500 concurrent users on the task management application using a load testing tool
Step 2: Navigate to the home page of the application and observe the loading time for initial content rendering
Step 3: Perform CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on tasks and measure response times for each action
Step 4: Check if all UI elements are responsive and interactive without any lag or freezing during high load conditions
Step 5: Monitor the application's performance metrics to ensure no server-side errors or timeouts occur
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management application should maintain an average response time of less than 1.5 seconds for all CRUD operations under a simulated load of 500 concurrent users, with no server-side errors reported.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system responsiveness during peak usage hours on both mobile and desktop devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the task management application remains responsive and performs optimally when a large number of users are simultaneously accessing it from both mobile and desktop browsers during peak usage hours.
preconditions: Simulate 600 concurrent users, 300 on mobile and 300 on desktop
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate 600 concurrent users (300 mobile and 300 desktop) on the task management application using a load testing tool
Step 2: Navigate to the home page of the application from both mobile and desktop browsers and observe the loading time for initial content rendering
Step 3: Perform CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on tasks simultaneously from both platforms and measure response times for each action
Step 4: Check if all UI elements are responsive and interactive without any lag or freezing during high load conditions
Step 5: Monitor the application's performance metrics to ensure no server-side errors or timeouts occur
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management application should maintain an average response time of less than 1.8 seconds for all CRUD operations under a simulated load of 600 concurrent users (300 mobile and 300 desktop), with no server-side errors reported.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure secure handling of user interface elements against XSS attacks
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system prevents Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) by sanitizing and escaping input in UI elements when transitioning between mobile and desktop views using Bootstrap.
preconditions: System is responsive on both mobile and desktop
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the system with a valid user account
Step 2: Navigate to the task management page where input fields are present (e.g., 'Add Task' form)
Step 3: Enter malicious script in an input field, such as '<script>alert('XSS')</script>'
Step 4: Switch between mobile and desktop view using Bootstrap responsive design features
Step 5: Verify that the entered script is not executed on either view by checking for alert box or similar behavior
Step 6: Confirm that the input field displays the exact malicious script without executing it
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must prevent the execution of any injected scripts, ensuring that user interface elements remain secure and responsive across different view modes.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate secure storage of session tokens when switching between mobile and desktop views
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system securely stores session tokens in client-side cookies or local storage, preventing unauthorized access during UI transitions.
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the system with a valid user account
Step 2: Inspect network traffic to identify session token being sent via cookies or local storage
Step 3: Switch between mobile and desktop view using Bootstrap responsive features
Step 4: Verify that the session token remains unchanged during UI transitions
Step 5: Confirm that the session token is stored securely in a HttpOnly cookie to prevent JavaScript access
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must maintain consistent and secure storage of session tokens during UI transitions, ensuring that the token is not exposed or altered.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent information leakage through UI elements during responsive design transitions
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that sensitive information is not inadvertently exposed in the user interface when switching between mobile and desktop views.
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the system with a valid user account
Step 2: Navigate to a page containing sensitive information (e.g., personal details or financial data)
Step 3: Switch between mobile and desktop view using Bootstrap responsive features
Step 4: Verify that no sensitive information is visible in UI elements during transitions
Step 5: Confirm that all sensitive fields are properly masked or hidden when not in use
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must ensure that no sensitive information is exposed during UI transitions, maintaining the confidentiality of user data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify clarity and placement of UI elements on task creation page
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that all necessary fields for creating a new task are clearly visible and placed appropriately to enhance user experience.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task creation page from the dashboard
Step 2: Observe the placement of the 'Title' field, ensuring it is at the top or immediately visible upon opening the form
Step 3: Check that the 'Description' text area is below the 'Title' field and large enough for detailed descriptions without scrolling within a typical viewport size
Step 4: Verify the presence of a 'Due Date' picker, ensuring it is easily accessible and clearly labeled
Step 5: Confirm that there are no overlapping or hidden UI elements when resizing the browser window to simulate different screen sizes
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All required fields for task creation are clearly visible and placed in a logical order, ensuring ease of use across different screen sizes without overlapping or hidden elements.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Evaluate task completion time for creating a new task on mobile and desktop
phase2_test_cases.description: Measure the time it takes to create a new task from start to finish, ensuring that the process is efficient and user-friendly across both platforms.
preconditions: User has access to both mobile and desktop versions of the system
test_steps: Step 1: On a mobile device, navigate to the task creation page
Step 2: Enter a title for the new task in the designated field
Step 3: Add a detailed description and select a due date using the provided calendar picker
Step 4: Click 'Save' or 'Create Task', timing how long it takes from opening the form to completing all fields and saving the task
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-4 on a desktop computer, comparing the time taken for each step
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The process of creating a new task should take no more than 30 seconds on both mobile and desktop platforms, ensuring efficient task management without delays.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate error message clarity when creating a new task with missing required fields
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that clear and concise error messages are displayed when attempting to create a new task without completing all mandatory fields.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task creation page on both mobile and desktop
Step 2: Leave the 'Title' field empty and attempt to save the new task
Step 3: Observe the error message displayed, ensuring it clearly indicates which fields are missing or invalid
Step 4: Repeat step 2 for other required fields such as 'Due Date', checking if error messages appear correctly each time
Step 5: Ensure that error messages provide guidance on how to correct the issue and do not cause confusion
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: When attempting to create a new task without completing all required fields, clear error messages are displayed indicating which fields need input and providing guidance on how to proceed.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify responsive UI on different screen sizes for desktop and mobile devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the user interface of a task management app is responsive across various screen sizes, including both desktop and mobile devices.
preconditions: User has access to multiple devices with varying screen resolutions
Task management application is installed or accessible via web
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task management application on a desktop browser with a resolution of 1920x1080
Step 2: Resize the window to simulate smaller screen sizes (e.g., 1366x768, 1024x768)
Step 3: Observe and record how UI elements such as task lists, buttons, and navigation bars adjust in size and position
Step 4: Open the same application on a mobile device with a resolution of 375x812 (iPhone X) or similar
Step 5: Scroll through different sections of the app to ensure no content is cut off or misaligned
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user interface elements should automatically adjust their size and layout to fit within the available screen space without overlapping, cutting off text, or requiring horizontal scrolling.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify consistent user interface across iOS and Android devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management app's UI is consistent in appearance and functionality between iOS and Android mobile operating systems.
preconditions: Access to both iOS and Android devices
Task management application installed or accessible via web
test_steps: Step 1: Install and launch the task management app on an iPhone with iOS version 14.0
Step 2: Perform basic tasks such as adding a new task, marking it complete, and deleting a task
Step 3: Repeat step 1 on an Android device running version 10 (Android Q)
Step 4: Compare the UI elements, layout, and functionality observed in both operating systems
Step 5: Ensure that all buttons, icons, text fields, and other interactive elements behave identically across platforms
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The user interface should be visually consistent with identical button placements, icon designs, and text formatting between iOS and Android devices. All core functionalities should work without any discrepancies.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task management app's performance on different network types (WiFi, 4G, 5G)
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management application performs well and functions correctly under varying internet connection conditions.
preconditions: Access to devices with WiFi, 4G, and 5G capabilities
Task management app installed or accessible via web
test_steps: Step 1: Connect a device to a stable WiFi network
Step 2: Add multiple tasks in the application and observe loading times for new task creation
Step 3: Disconnect from WiFi and switch to 4G cellular data, then repeat step 2
Step 4: Switch to 5G if available and perform the same task addition process again
Step 5: Monitor network usage and application response time during each connection type
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Tasks should be added successfully within a reasonable timeframe (e.g., less than 2 seconds) regardless of whether the device is connected to WiFi, 4G, or 5G networks. Network data usage should remain within acceptable limits.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system responsiveness on mobile and desktop using Bootstrap
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the API returns responses within specified time limits when accessed from both mobile and desktop environments.
preconditions: User is authenticated with a valid JWT token
API endpoint is configured to use Bootstrap for responsive design
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> from a mobile device
Step 2: Measure the response time and ensure it does not exceed 2 seconds
Step 3: Verify that the HTTP status code returned is 200 OK
Step 4: Send GET request to /api/todos with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> from a desktop browser
Step 5: Measure the response time and ensure it does not exceed 2 seconds
Step 6: Verify that the HTTP status code returned is 200 OK
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API response time does not exceed 2 seconds and returns an HTTP status code of 200 OK for both mobile and desktop environments.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate sorting functionality across different devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the API supports sorting of tasks by date and title, and this sorting is consistent on both mobile and desktop interfaces.
preconditions: User has multiple todos with varying dates and titles
API endpoint allows for query parameters to sort data
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos?sort=date with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> from a mobile device
Step 2: Verify that the todos are returned in ascending order by date
Step 3: Send GET request to /api/todos?sort=title with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> from a desktop browser
Step 4: Verify that the todos are returned in alphabetical order by title
Step 5: Ensure that the sorting behavior is consistent and does not vary between mobile and desktop interfaces
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Todos are returned in ascending order by date when sorted with 'date' query parameter, and in alphabetical order by title when sorted with 'title' query parameter. Sorting behavior is consistent across mobile and desktop interfaces.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Check rate limiting on API endpoints for responsiveness
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system enforces rate limits to prevent abuse and maintain performance, especially when accessed from both mobile and desktop.
preconditions: Rate limiting is configured on /api/todos endpoint
User has a valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send 50 GET requests to /api/todos with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> from a mobile device within a short timeframe
Step 2: Verify that the API returns HTTP status code 429 Too Many Requests after reaching the rate limit
Step 3: Wait for the cooldown period specified in the rate limiting configuration
Step 4: Send another GET request to /api/todos from a desktop browser and verify successful response with HTTP status code 200 OK
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API returns an HTTP status code of 429 Too Many Requests after the user sends more than 50 requests within a short timeframe, and resumes normal operation with HTTP status code 200 OK once the rate limit cooldown period has passed.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure data consistency during task creation via API
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system maintains data integrity when a new task is created through the API.
preconditions: User authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"title": "Create Task", "description": "This is a test task description", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains created task with auto-generated ID and timestamp fields
Step 5: Retrieve the newly created task via GET /api/tasks/{task_id} to ensure data consistency
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return HTTP 201 status code with the newly created task ID and ensure that all fields in the response match the input data, maintaining data consistency.

test_data.actual_description: This is a test task description

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate foreign key relationships during task deletion via UI
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system maintains data integrity by validating foreign key relationships when a task is deleted through the user interface.
preconditions: User authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Management page and locate an existing task
Step 2: Click on the 'Delete' button associated with the selected task
Step 3: Confirm deletion by clicking 'Yes, delete'
Step 4: Verify that the system returns a success message indicating the task was deleted successfully
Step 5: Check if any related entities (e.g., comments, attachments) are also removed or marked as inactive
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a success message confirming the task deletion and ensure that all related entities are appropriately handled, maintaining data integrity.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure transactional consistency during bulk task updates via API
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system maintains data integrity by ensuring transactional consistency when updating multiple tasks in a single request.
preconditions: User authenticated with valid JWT token
Multiple tasks exist and are selected for update
test_steps: Step 1: Send PATCH request to /api/tasks/bulk with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"tasks": [{"id": "task_id_1", "completed": true}, {"id": "task_id_2", "completed": true}] }
Step 3: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned indicating successful update
Step 4: Retrieve the updated tasks via GET /api/tasks to ensure all specified updates were applied correctly
Step 5: Confirm that no partial or inconsistent data exists in the system
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return HTTP 200 status code and ensure that all specified tasks are updated to the completed state, maintaining transactional consistency.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management API - Bulk Task Updates

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Recovery During Task Creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system can recover from a network interruption while creating a new task and resume operation once connectivity is restored.
test_steps: Step 1: Initiate task creation on mobile device with title 'Test Task'
Step 2: Simulate network disconnection during the submission of the task
Step 3: Observe UI behavior and ensure a message indicating network issues is displayed
Step 4: Re-establish network connection and attempt to submit the task again
Step 5: Verify that the task creation request completes successfully with HTTP status code 201
Step 6: Confirm that the newly created task appears in the user's task list
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a network error message and allow the task creation to proceed once connectivity is restored, with the newly created task appearing in the user's task list.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery During Task Deletion
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can recover from an app crash during task deletion and restore user session upon reopening.
preconditions: Task list with at least one task
test_steps: Step 1: Select a task for deletion on desktop browser
Step 2: Trigger app crash while the delete operation is pending (e.g., through force close)
Step 3: Reopen the application and navigate back to the task list page
Step 4: Verify that the system prompts the user with an option to retry or cancel the previous deletion attempt
Step 5: Confirm that upon selecting 'Retry', the task is successfully deleted from the server
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon reopening the application, the system should detect an interrupted deletion operation and offer a retry option. The task must be deleted successfully when 'Retry' is selected.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: GPS Signal Loss During Task Location Assignment
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system handles GPS signal loss gracefully when assigning a location to a task.
test_steps: Step 1: Start creating a new task on mobile device and attempt to assign a location using GPS
Step 2: Simulate GPS signal loss during the assignment process
Step 3: Ensure that the system alerts the user about the lost GPS connection
Step 4: Re-enable GPS access and complete the task creation with location assignment
Step 5: Verify that the newly created task includes the assigned location
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should notify the user of GPS signal loss and allow them to re-enable GPS access. The task must be successfully created with the correct location upon resuming.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Responsive Design - Minimum Screen Width Test
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system's user interface remains responsive and functional on devices with a minimum screen width of 320 pixels.
test_steps: Step 1: Resize browser window to have a width of exactly 320 pixels
Step 2: Navigate to the task management homepage and observe layout adjustments
Step 3: Click on 'Add Task' button and ensure modal dialog appears without overlap or distortion
Step 4: Enter task details in input fields (Title, Description) and verify that all elements are fully visible and accessible
Step 5: Submit the new task and confirm it is added to the list with correct styling and layout adjustments
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system's user interface should adjust to the minimum screen width of 320 pixels, ensuring all UI elements are fully visible and functional without overlap or distortion.

task_details.title: Test Task
task_details.description: This is a test description for boundary testing.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Responsive Design - Maximum Screen Width Test
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system's user interface remains responsive and functional on devices with a maximum screen width of 1920 pixels.
test_steps: Step 1: Resize browser window to have a width of exactly 1920 pixels
Step 2: Navigate to the task management homepage and observe layout adjustments
Step 3: Click on 'Filter Tasks' dropdown menu and ensure all options are visible without requiring horizontal scrolling
Step 4: Apply multiple filters (e.g., by date, status) and verify that filtered tasks are displayed correctly with proper alignment
Step 5: Scroll down to the bottom of the page and confirm that footer elements remain fixed at the bottom without overlapping content
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system's user interface should adjust to the maximum screen width of 1920 pixels, ensuring all UI elements are fully visible and functional without overlap or distortion.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Responsive Design - Mobile/Tablet Breakpoint Test
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system's user interface transitions smoothly between mobile and tablet breakpoints (e.g., 768px for tablets, 1024px for larger screens).
test_steps: Step 1: Resize browser window to have a width of exactly 768 pixels (tablet breakpoint)
Step 2: Navigate to the task management homepage and observe layout adjustments
Step 3: Click on 'Settings' menu icon and ensure it expands into a full navigation bar without overlap or distortion
Step 4: Resize browser window to have a width of exactly 1024 pixels (larger screen breakpoint)
Step 5: Observe that the layout adjusts back to desktop mode with no overlapping elements
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system's user interface should transition smoothly between mobile and tablet breakpoints, ensuring all UI elements are fully visible and functional without overlap or distortion.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle responsive layout issues on mobile devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system maintains a responsive and functional UI when transitioning from desktop to mobile view using Bootstrap.
preconditions: System is running on a mobile device
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page while the system is set up for mobile view
Step 2: Verify that all UI elements are visible and accessible without requiring horizontal scrolling or zooming
Step 3: Attempt to create a new task by clicking on the 'Add Task' button and entering task details in the form
Step 4: Check if the form fields resize appropriately for mobile input, ensuring no data entry issues arise due to layout constraints
Step 5: Confirm that after submitting the task, it appears correctly in the list view without any overlapping or misalignment of elements
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display all UI elements correctly and allow seamless task creation and viewing without any layout issues or data entry problems.

test_data.task_description: This is a test description to ensure proper layout on mobile devices.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure proper error handling when switching between desktop and mobile views
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system gracefully handles errors or inconsistencies in UI elements when transitioning between different screen sizes.
preconditions: System supports both desktop and mobile views
test_steps: Step 1: Start with a fully functional task management page on a desktop view
Step 2: Resize the browser window to simulate a mobile device, triggering layout changes according to Bootstrap
Step 3: Attempt to edit an existing task by clicking the 'Edit' button and making modifications in the form
Step 4: Switch back to full-screen mode (desktop view) while the form is still open for editing
Step 5: Verify that upon switching back, the system maintains the state of the form without any data loss or UI corruption
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon switching back to desktop view, the system should retain the state of any open forms or editing tasks without displaying error messages or losing data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate consistent UI behavior across different screen sizes during task deletion
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system handles task deletions smoothly without any layout or functionality issues when switching between desktop and mobile views.
preconditions: System supports both desktop and mobile views
test_steps: Step 1: Ensure there are at least three tasks visible on the task management page
Step 2: Resize the browser window to simulate a mobile device, ensuring that all tasks are still visible but may be stacked or rearranged
Step 3: Select one of the tasks and initiate deletion by clicking the 'Delete' button
Step 4: Confirm the deletion action on both the mobile view and then switch back to desktop view immediately after confirmation
Step 5: Verify that the deleted task is no longer visible in either view, with proper UI updates reflecting the change
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should consistently remove the selected task from both views without any layout issues or errors, and properly update the UI to reflect the deletion.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test for Task Creation in High Concurrent Environment
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system can handle high concurrent task creation without performance degradation.
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate 50 users logging into the application simultaneously using JMeter or similar tool
Step 2: Each user creates a new task with title 'Task Creation Test' and sets completion status to false
Step 3: Monitor system response time for each task creation request, ensuring it does not exceed 1 second
Step 4: Verify that all tasks are successfully created in the database within 2 minutes of the first request
Step 5: Check the UI dashboard to confirm all tasks appear correctly without any lag or delay
Step 6: Ensure no errors or timeouts occur during the task creation process
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle simultaneous task creations by 50 users without performance degradation, with each request completing within 1 second and all tasks appearing on the UI dashboard within 2 minutes.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test for Sorting Tasks by Priority in Large Dataset
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the system's performance when sorting tasks based on priority in a large dataset.
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the application with an admin account
Step 2: Navigate to the task management page and select 'Priority' from the sort dropdown menu
Step 3: Measure the time taken for the system to display all tasks sorted by priority, ensuring it does not exceed 5 seconds
Step 4: Verify that the first 10 tasks displayed are indeed the highest priority tasks
Step 5: Scroll down and check that subsequent tasks are correctly ordered according to their priority level
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should sort and display 10,000 tasks by priority within 5 seconds, with the first 10 being the highest priority and all subsequent tasks correctly ordered.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test for Filtering Tasks by Due Date in High Volume Environment
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the system's performance when filtering tasks based on due date in a high volume environment.
preconditions: Login as a user with access to multiple projects
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the application and navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Set the due date filter to 'Today' using the calendar widget
Step 3: Measure the time taken for the system to display all tasks with a due date set for today, ensuring it does not exceed 4 seconds
Step 4: Verify that only tasks with a due date set for the current day are displayed
Step 5: Change the filter to 'Tomorrow' and measure the response time again
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should filter and display 5,000 tasks with a due date set for today within 4 seconds, showing only those tasks and not any others.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent unauthorized access to user interface elements
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that only authenticated users can access certain UI elements such as task management features.
preconditions: Task management page URL is known
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page without being logged in
Step 2: Attempt to add a new task by clicking on 'Add Task' button
Step 3: Verify that an authentication modal or login prompt appears instead of allowing access to the task creation form
Step 4: Enter incorrect credentials and attempt to log in, verify that an error message is displayed indicating invalid credentials
Step 5: Attempt to directly manipulate URL parameters for adding tasks (e.g., appending '/add' to the URL) without being logged in, verify redirection or display of login modal
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should prevent unauthorized access by displaying an authentication modal and not allowing direct manipulation of task creation URLs without proper credentials.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure secure handling of sensitive data in user interface
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system does not expose any sensitive information such as API keys or database credentials through UI elements.
preconditions: User is logged in with admin privileges
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the application's settings page
Step 2: Check for presence of any fields that might contain sensitive information such as API keys or database credentials
Step 3: Attempt to modify or view sensitive data through these fields, verify that no actual sensitive data is displayed and modifications are not allowed
Step 4: Inspect the network traffic using a tool like Fiddler or Chrome DevTools Network tab while attempting to access sensitive information
Step 5: Verify that no sensitive data is transmitted over the network in plain text
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should securely handle any sensitive data by not displaying it on UI elements and ensuring no sensitive information is exposed through network traffic.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks on user interface elements
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system is protected against XSS by properly sanitizing and escaping input from users.
preconditions: User has access to task description field
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task creation or editing page
Step 2: Enter a malicious script in the task description field (e.g., <script>alert('XSS');</script>)
Step 3: Submit the form with the malicious input and verify that no alert box is triggered on the client side
Step 4: Inspect the server response to ensure that the input was properly sanitized and does not contain any executable scripts
Step 5: Verify that the task description in the database or subsequent display of the task does not include any script tags
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should prevent XSS attacks by properly sanitizing user inputs and ensuring that no executable scripts are stored or displayed in task descriptions.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify clarity and placement of UI elements for task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the user interface is straightforward by validating the clarity and proper placement of UI elements during task creation.
preconditions: User logged in to the application
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task creation form within the Task Management section
Step 2: Observe the layout of input fields such as 'Title', 'Description', and 'Due Date'
Step 3: Ensure that each field label is clear, concise, and directly above or next to its corresponding input element
Step 4: Verify that there are no overlapping UI elements and all necessary fields are visible without scrolling
Step 5: Confirm the presence of a 'Create Task' button at the bottom of the form
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All input fields for task creation should be clearly labeled, properly placed, and easily accessible to ensure users can create tasks efficiently.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Evaluate the intuitiveness of navigation for task management features
phase2_test_cases.description: Assess whether users can navigate through different sections of the application to manage tasks without confusion.
test_steps: Step 1: Click on 'Tasks' from the main menu or dashboard
Step 2: Check if a sidebar navigation appears with options like 'All Tasks', 'Completed', and 'Overdue'
Step 3: Select 'All Tasks' to view all tasks in a list format
Step 4: Click on 'Filter' option from the top menu bar to apply filters such as 'Due Date' or 'Priority'
Step 5: Confirm that navigating back to the main task page is straightforward and does not require multiple clicks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Navigation should be intuitive, allowing users to easily switch between different views of tasks without encountering any dead ends or complex navigation paths.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Test error message clarity when creating a task with missing required fields
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system provides clear and understandable error messages when attempting to create a task without completing all mandatory fields.
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task creation form within Task Management
Step 2: Leave the 'Title' field empty and attempt to submit the form by clicking 'Create Task'
Step 3: Verify that an error message appears indicating which fields are required but missing (in this case, 'Title')
Step 4: Ensure that the error message is displayed prominently near or directly above the missing input field
Step 5: Confirm that upon clicking on the error message, it provides additional guidance on how to correct the issue
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: When a user attempts to create a task without filling out all required fields, an explicit and clear error message should appear indicating which field(s) need to be completed.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify consistent UI behavior across iOS and Android devices for task management app
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the user interface remains straightforward and consistent in its presentation of tasks on both iOS and Android platforms.
preconditions: Install the latest version of the task management app on an iPhone 12
Install the same version of the task management app on a Samsung Galaxy S20
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the task management app on both devices
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Add Task' screen and observe the layout, button placement, and text size for consistency across platforms
Step 3: Add a new task titled 'Test Compatibility' with due date set for tomorrow and save it. Verify that the task appears in the list on both devices.
Step 4: Swipe left or right to delete the added task and confirm its removal from the task list on both iOS and Android
Step 5: Check if the app's navigation drawer (hamburger menu) is accessible and contains all expected items such as 'Tasks', 'Settings', etc., with identical layout and functionality
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management app should display the 'Add Task' screen with consistent layout and button placement on both iOS and Android devices. The added task titled 'Test Compatibility' must be visible in the task list, and its deletion must be reflected identically across platforms.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task sorting functionality on different screen sizes and resolutions for web-based productivity tool
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the user can sort tasks by priority, due date, or completion status across various screen sizes and resolutions.
preconditions: Open the web-based productivity tool in Chrome with a resolution of 1920x1080
Adjust browser window size to simulate smaller screens such as 768x1024
test_steps: Step 1: Log into the web-based productivity tool and navigate to the task management page
Step 2: Click on the 'Sort By' dropdown menu and select 'Priority'. Observe how tasks are reordered based on priority level
Step 3: Change browser window size to simulate a tablet view (768x1024) and repeat Step 2. Verify that sorting functionality remains consistent across screen sizes
Step 4: Click on the 'Sort By' dropdown again and select 'Due Date'. Confirm that tasks are sorted according to their due dates, with closest deadlines appearing first
Step 5: Resize browser window back to desktop view (1920x1080) and sort by completion status. Ensure incomplete tasks appear above completed ones
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The web-based productivity tool must allow users to sort tasks by priority, due date, or completion status across different screen sizes and resolutions. Tasks should be reordered correctly based on the selected sorting criteria.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure accurate GPS location tracking in task management app across various network types (WiFi, 4G, 5G)
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the application can accurately track and display user's current location for geotagging tasks regardless of network conditions.
preconditions: Connect to a WiFi network with known IP address
Switch to mobile data plan with 4G or 5G connectivity
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task management app and grant permission for location access
Step 2: Connect to a stable WiFi network (e.g., home Wi-Fi) and create a new task titled 'WiFi Location Test'. Add current GPS coordinates as geotag
Step 3: Switch to mobile data plan with 4G or 5G connectivity. Create another task named 'Mobile Data Location Test' and add the updated location details
Step 4: Verify that both tasks ('WiFi Location Test', 'Mobile Data Location Test') are correctly geotagged with accurate GPS coordinates on the map view
Step 5: Check if the app's location tracking feature remains responsive and does not lag or fail to update positions under varying network conditions
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management app must accurately track and display the user's current location for geotagging tasks across different network types (WiFi, 4G, 5G). Both 'WiFi Location Test' and 'Mobile Data Location Test' tasks should be correctly geotagged with precise GPS coordinates.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify successful creation of a new task
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that a user can create a new task via the API and it appears in the UI.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
User has permission to create tasks
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"title": "Read book", "description": "Finish reading the novel", "priority": "High", "due_date": "2023-12-31T23:59:59Z"}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains created task with auto-generated ID and timestamp
Step 5: Navigate to the Task Management UI page and verify that the newly created task is displayed in the list
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API response should return a status code of 201, with a new task ID generated and timestamp included. The newly created task titled 'Read book' must appear in the Task Management UI page.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify deletion of a task via API
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that deleting a task through the API removes it from both the database and UI.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/tasks/{task_id} to retrieve the task details
Step 2: Verify that the task is present and has a status code of 200
Step 3: Send DELETE request to /api/tasks/{task_id} with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify HTTP 204 status code returned indicating successful deletion
Step 5: Navigate to the Task Management UI page and verify that the task is no longer displayed
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API response should return a status code of 204 after deleting the task. The task with ID {task_id} must not be visible in the Task Management UI page.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify sorting tasks by priority level via API
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks can be sorted in the UI based on their priority levels using the API.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
Multiple tasks exist in the system
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/tasks?sort=priority with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 3: Check response body for tasks sorted by priority level (High, Medium, Low)
Step 4: Navigate to the Task Management UI page and verify that tasks are displayed in order of their priority levels
Step 5: Send GET request again with different sort parameter e.g., /api/tasks?sort=priority&order=desc
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API response should return a status code of 200 and tasks sorted by priority levels in ascending order. The Task Management UI page must display the same sorting behavior.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure mandatory fields are validated upon task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system enforces mandatory field validation during task creation in the Task Management module.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Create New Task' form on the Task Management UI
Step 2: Leave the 'Title' field empty and click 'Save'
Step 3: Verify that an error message appears indicating the 'Title' is a required field
Step 4: Enter a title in the 'Title' field but leave other mandatory fields (e.g., 'Due Date') blank
Step 5: Click 'Save' and verify that an error message appears for each missing mandatory field
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon attempting to save a task without completing all mandatory fields, the system should display specific error messages next to each incomplete required field.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate data type constraints for task duration fields
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system correctly validates the data types of numeric input fields such as 'Duration' in minutes.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Edit Task Details' form
Step 2: Enter a non-numeric value (e.g., 'abc') into the 'Duration' field and attempt to save
Step 3: Verify that an error message appears indicating invalid input for the 'Duration' field
Step 4: Enter a negative number (-10) in the 'Duration' field and attempt to save
Step 5: Verify that an error message appears stating that the duration must be positive
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display specific validation errors when non-numeric or negative values are entered into the 'Duration' field, ensuring data type constraints are enforced.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Check for transaction integrity during task deletion
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system maintains data consistency when deleting tasks, particularly in relation to associated comments and attachments.
preconditions: Task with associated comments and attachments exists
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to a task page with existing comments and attachments
Step 2: Click the 'Delete Task' button and confirm deletion
Step 3: Verify that the task is removed from the list of tasks
Step 4: Check the database or system logs for confirmation of task deletion
Step 5: Ensure all associated comments and attachments are also deleted
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon deleting a task, the system should ensure that all associated comments and attachments are also removed, maintaining transaction integrity.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During Task Creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system gracefully handles network interruptions during task creation and recovers once connectivity is restored.
test_steps: Step 1: Initiate task creation process by clicking 'Add Task' button
Step 2: Enter task title 'Test Task' and set completion status to false
Step 3: Simulate network interruption (e.g., disconnect Wi-Fi or mobile data)
Step 4: Observe UI displays a notification indicating network connection loss
Step 5: Re-establish internet connectivity after a brief period
