Step 6: Verify that the system automatically retries task creation and successfully adds 'Test Task' to the list
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a network connection error message, then upon re-establishing connectivity, it should automatically retry task creation and add 'Test Task' to the user's task list with no data loss.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery During Task Editing
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system can recover from an app crash during task editing and retains all unsaved changes upon reopening.
preconditions: Task editing page open with unsaved changes
test_steps: Step 1: Open a task for editing, modify its title to 'Edited Task' without saving
Step 2: Force close the app (e.g., via device settings or task manager)
Step 3: Reopen the application and navigate back to the task editing page
Step 4: Confirm that the previously edited task is still open with the title 'Edited Task'
Step 5: Save changes by clicking 'Save' button, verify task updates on main task list
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should retain all unsaved edits made to a task before the app crash and allow for seamless continuation of editing upon reopening.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management Feature - App Crash Recovery

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Data Persistence Across Multiple Crashes During Task Deletion
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that task deletion operations are successfully completed and persisted even after multiple app crashes.
preconditions: Task list with at least one task
test_steps: Step 1: Select a task for deletion by clicking the 'Delete' button
Step 2: Force close the application before confirming the delete action
Step 3: Reopen and log back into the app, navigate to the task list page
Step 4: Confirm that the selected task is still present in the list
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-3 two more times for a total of three crashes during deletion process
Step 6: After final crash recovery, confirm delete action and verify task removal from list
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should maintain the state of tasks marked for deletion across multiple app crashes until the user confirms the deletion action.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management Feature - Data Persistence Across Crashes

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure task title field does not accept empty string input
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system enforces a non-empty task title when creating a new task.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Create Task' form on the user interface
Step 2: Clear all characters from the 'Title' input field
Step 3: Click the 'Submit' button without entering any text in the title field
Step 4: Verify that an error message is displayed indicating that the task title cannot be empty
Step 5: Ensure that no new task is created and the user remains on the 'Create Task' form
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: An error message should be displayed stating 'Task title cannot be empty', preventing submission of a task with an empty title.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify maximum character limit for task description field
phase2_test_cases.description: Check that the system enforces a maximum of 500 characters in the 'Description' field.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Create Task' form on the user interface
Step 2: Enter exactly 500 characters into the 'Description' input field using a predefined string of text
Step 3: Click the 'Submit' button after entering the maximum allowed characters
Step 4: Verify that the task is successfully created with all entered description data
Step 5: Attempt to enter one more character (making it 501 characters) and verify an error message indicating that the limit has been exceeded
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task should be created with exactly 500 characters in the description, and an error message should appear if more than 500 characters are entered.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate sorting behavior for task list by due date
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that tasks can be sorted correctly in ascending and descending order based on their due dates.
preconditions: Multiple tasks with different due dates are present
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Task List' page
Step 2: Click on the 'Due Date' column header to sort tasks by ascending order
Step 3: Verify that all tasks are sorted in chronological order based on their due dates from earliest to latest
Step 4: Click on the 'Due Date' column header again to reverse the sorting order
Step 5: Confirm that the task list is now sorted in descending order, with due dates from latest to earliest
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Tasks should be displayed in ascending order when 'Due Date' is clicked once and then in descending order upon clicking it a second time.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle missing required fields in task creation form
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system provides clear error messages when a user tries to create a new task without filling out mandatory fields.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Creation form
Step 2: Leave the 'Title' field empty and fill other required fields such as 'Description'
Step 3: Click on the 'Create Task' button
Step 4: Verify that an error message is displayed next to the 'Title' field indicating it cannot be left blank
Step 5: Ensure that no new task is created in the system and the user remains on the same page with form data intact
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message next to the 'Title' field stating 'This field is required.' and prevent task creation until the missing information is provided.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate incorrect date format in due date field
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system provides a clear error message when an invalid date is entered into the 'Due Date' field.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Creation form
Step 2: Enter an incorrect date format (e.g., 'abcd') in the 'Due Date' field
Step 3: Click on the 'Create Task' button
Step 4: Verify that an error message is displayed next to the 'Due Date' field indicating the correct date format required
Step 5: Ensure that no new task is created and the user remains on the same page with form data intact
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message next to the 'Due Date' field stating 'Please enter a valid date in YYYY-MM-DD format.' and prevent task creation until a correct date is provided.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle server-side validation failure for duplicate tasks
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system provides a clear error message when attempting to create a task with an identical title and description as an existing task.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Creation form
Step 2: Enter details of an already existing task (Title, Description)
Step 3: Click on the 'Create Task' button
Step 4: Verify that a server-side validation error message is displayed indicating that a task with the same title and description already exists
Step 5: Ensure that no new duplicate task is created in the system and the user remains on the same page with form data intact
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a server-side validation error message stating 'A task with this title and description already exists.' and prevent the creation of duplicate tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test for System Navigation Speed
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the performance of system navigation by measuring the time taken to navigate through different pages and features.
preconditions: System is running on a standard configuration
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate from the home page to the tasks list page
Step 2: Click on 'Add Task' button to open task creation form
Step 3: Fill out all mandatory fields and submit the form
Step 4: Verify that the new task appears in the task list within 1 second
Step 5: Navigate back to home page by clicking on the navigation menu link
Step 6: Click on 'Settings' option from the navigation menu and verify settings page loads within 2 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should navigate between pages and load new features within the specified time limits, ensuring a smooth user experience.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test for Task Sorting Functionality
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the performance of task sorting functionality by measuring the time taken to sort tasks based on different criteria.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the tasks list page
Step 2: Click on 'Sort By' dropdown and select 'Due Date'
Step 3: Verify that all tasks are sorted by due date within 5 seconds
Step 4: Change sort criteria to 'Priority' from the dropdown menu
Step 5: Verify that all tasks are now sorted based on priority level within 5 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should sort the task list by selected criteria (due date, priority) within a maximum of 5 seconds for up to 50 tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Performance Test for Task Filtering Functionality
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the performance of task filtering functionality by measuring the time taken to filter tasks based on different criteria.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the tasks list page
Step 2: Click on 'Filter By' dropdown and select 'Completed'
Step 3: Verify that all completed tasks are displayed within 5 seconds
Step 4: Change filter criteria to 'Overdue' from the dropdown menu
Step 5: Verify that only overdue tasks are now visible within 5 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should filter the task list by selected criteria (completed, overdue) within a maximum of 5 seconds for up to 100 tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent unauthorized access to navigation system configuration
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that only authorized users can modify the navigation system's configuration settings.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'System Configuration' page via the main menu
Step 2: Click on the 'Navigation Settings' tab within the configuration panel
Step 3: Attempt to change the 'Default View Mode' setting from 'Grid' to 'List'
Step 4: Verify that the system responds with a HTTP 200 status code indicating successful modification
Step 5: Confirm that the updated view mode is reflected in subsequent page loads
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should allow the user to change the 'Default View Mode' setting and reflect this change on all subsequent navigation requests.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent unauthorized access to system-wide navigation settings
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that non-administrative users cannot modify the global navigation settings.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid JWT token
User does not have administrative privileges
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a standard user and navigate to the 'System Configuration' page
Step 2: Attempt to access the 'Navigation Settings' tab within the configuration panel
Step 3: Verify that the system redirects the user back to their dashboard or displays an error message indicating insufficient permissions
Step 4: Confirm that attempting to modify any navigation settings results in a HTTP 403 status code
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should prevent non-administrative users from accessing or modifying the 'Navigation Settings' tab and return a HTTP 403 status code when such attempts are made.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent SQL injection attacks on navigation settings form submission
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system is protected against SQL injection when submitting changes to navigation settings.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'System Configuration' page and access the 'Navigation Settings' tab
Step 2: Enter an SQL injection payload (e.g., ' OR '1'='1') in the 'Default View Mode' input field
Step 3: Submit the form with the malicious data
Step 4: Verify that the system logs the attempted attack and returns a HTTP 500 status code or similar error response
Step 5: Confirm that no changes are made to the navigation settings as a result of the submitted payload
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should detect and reject SQL injection attempts, logging the incident and returning an HTTP 500 status code or similar error message without applying any changes to navigation settings.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify navigation intuitiveness for task management features
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the navigation elements are clear and intuitive, allowing users to easily access all task management features.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the home page of the task management application
Step 2: Hover over the navigation bar and observe the hover effects on each menu item
Step 3: Click on the 'Tasks' menu item from the navigation bar
Step 4: Verify that a new page opens displaying all tasks with clear labels for different sections such as 'To Do', 'In Progress', and 'Completed'
Step 5: Use the breadcrumb navigation at the top of the page to navigate back to the home page
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The navigation bar should clearly display all task management features with hover effects and breadcrumb navigation allowing users to easily navigate back to the home page.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate error message clarity when adding a new task
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that clear and specific error messages are displayed when users encounter issues while adding a new task.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Add Task' page from the navigation bar
Step 2: Leave all required fields blank and click on the 'Save' button
Step 3: Observe the error message displayed below each field indicating that it is a required field
Step 4: Enter an invalid date format in the due date field and attempt to save the task
Step 5: Verify that an error message appears stating 'Invalid date format. Please use YYYY-MM-DD.'
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Clear and specific error messages should be displayed for each required field left blank or when an invalid date format is entered.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Evaluate mobile vs desktop experience differences in task management system
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system provides a consistent and intuitive user experience across both mobile and desktop platforms.
test_steps: Step 1: Access the task management application on a desktop browser
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Tasks' page and verify that all tasks are displayed with clear labels for different sections
Step 3: Switch to mobile view by resizing the browser window or using a mobile device
Step 4: Verify that the navigation bar collapses into a hamburger menu and that all task management features remain accessible
Step 5: Add a new task from the mobile view and verify that it is displayed correctly on both desktop and mobile views
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should provide a consistent and intuitive user experience across both desktop and mobile platforms, with navigation elements adapting to the screen size.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Navigation bar visibility on different screen sizes
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the navigation bar is visible and functional across various screen resolutions and device types.
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the application on an iPhone SE with a resolution of 375x667 pixels
Step 2: Navigate to the main task management page and verify that the navigation bar is visible at the top of the screen
Step 3: Rotate the device to landscape mode and confirm that the navigation bar remains visible and functional
Step 4: Repeat steps 1-3 on an Android tablet with a resolution of 800x1280 pixels
Step 5: Verify that the navigation bar adjusts its layout appropriately for both portrait and landscape orientations
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The navigation bar must be visible, functional, and adjust its layout appropriately for both portrait and landscape orientations on all tested devices.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Location accuracy impact on task reminders
phase2_test_cases.description: Test the reliability of location-based task reminders under varying GPS and network conditions.
test_steps: Step 1: Set up a task reminder that triggers based on proximity to a specific location
Step 2: Place the device near the designated location while connected to a stable WiFi network and verify that the reminder is triggered accurately
Step 3: Move away from the WiFi area but remain within range of a reliable 4G signal
Step 4: Confirm that the task reminder still triggers correctly despite switching networks
Step 5: Repeat steps 1-4 in an environment with poor GPS reception and verify that the reminder is delayed or not triggered at all
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Task reminders based on location should trigger accurately under both WiFi and 4G conditions, but may be delayed or fail in areas with poor GPS reception.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Create a new todo item and verify its creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that creating a new todo item via the API results in successful creation and proper response data.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/todos with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"title": "Buy groceries", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains created todo item with auto-generated ID
Step 5: Verify response body includes 'createdAt' timestamp in ISO format
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API returns HTTP status code 201 and the response body contains a new todo item with title 'Buy groceries', completed set to false, an auto-generated ID, and a 'createdAt' timestamp in ISO format.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Retrieve all todo items for an authenticated user
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that retrieving all todo items via the API returns a list of items with proper data.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
At least one todo item exists
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 3: Verify response body contains an array of todo items
Step 4: For each item in the array, verify it has 'id', 'title', and 'completed' fields
Step 5: Verify that all items have a 'createdAt' timestamp
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API returns HTTP status code 200 and the response body contains an array of todo items, each with an 'id', 'title', 'completed', and 'createdAt' field.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Update a todo item's completion status via API
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that updating the completion status of a todo item via the API results in successful update and proper response data.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
At least one incomplete todo item exists
test_steps: Step 1: Send PUT request to /api/todos/<todo_id> with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"completed": true}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 200 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains updated todo item with 'completed' set to true
Step 5: Send GET request to /api/todos/<todo_id> and verify that the retrieved item's 'completed' field is now true
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API returns HTTP status code 200, the response body contains an updated todo item with 'completed' set to true, and a subsequent GET request confirms that the item's completion status is now true.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validation of mandatory fields during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that all mandatory fields are correctly validated and enforced when creating a new task.
preconditions: Task management system is up and running
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Create Task' page via the navigation menu
Step 2: Attempt to create a new task without entering any data in mandatory fields such as 'Title'
Step 3: Submit the form and observe error messages for missing mandatory field(s)
Step 4: Verify that the system prevents submission until all mandatory fields are filled out correctly
Step 5: Enter valid data into all mandatory fields and submit the task creation form successfully
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the 'Title' field is required, and submission of the form should be blocked until this mandatory field is filled out. Upon successful entry of all mandatory fields, a new task should appear in the list with correct data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verification of integer field constraints during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system enforces data type constraints for fields expecting integer values.
preconditions: Task management system is up and running
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Create Task' page via the navigation menu
Step 2: Enter a non-integer value (e.g., 'abc') into an integer field such as 'Priority'
Step 3: Attempt to submit the form and verify that the system displays an error message indicating invalid input for the integer field
Step 4: Correctly enter an integer value within the allowed range (1-5) in the 'Priority' field
Step 5: Submit the form successfully with valid integer data
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the input for the 'Priority' field is invalid and must be a number within the specified range (1-5). Upon entering a valid integer value, the task creation process should proceed without errors.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validation of foreign key relationships during task assignment
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system correctly validates and enforces foreign key constraints when assigning tasks to users.
preconditions: Task management system is up and running
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Assign Task' page via the navigation menu
Step 2: Attempt to assign a task to an invalid user ID (e.g., non-existent or deleted user)
Step 3: Verify that the system displays an error message indicating that the selected user does not exist
Step 4: Correctly select a valid existing user from the dropdown menu and attempt to assign the task
Step 5: Confirm that the task is successfully assigned to the specified user with correct foreign key relationship
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message indicating that the selected 'AssignedToUserID' does not exist or is invalid. Upon selecting a valid existing user, the task assignment process should proceed without errors and the task should be correctly assigned to the specified user.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During Task Creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system can recover from a network interruption while creating a new task and ensure data persistence.
test_steps: Step 1: Initiate task creation by entering 'title' as 'Buy groceries' and setting 'completed' to false
Step 2: Simulate network interruption during the submission of the task (e.g., disable Wi-Fi or cellular data)
Step 3: Re-enable network connection after a short delay
Step 4: Verify that the system prompts the user with a message indicating 'Network is back, retrying task creation'
Step 5: Confirm that the task appears in the list of tasks after re-enabling the network
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a message indicating 'Network is back, retrying task creation' and successfully create the task with title 'Buy groceries' after re-establishing network connection.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Network Interruption Handling

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery During Task Editing
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can recover from an app crash while editing a task and maintain data integrity.
test_steps: Step 1: Open an existing task for editing, change 'title' to 'Prepare presentation'
Step 2: Simulate app crash (e.g., force close the application)
Step 3: Reopen the application and navigate back to the task list
Step 4: Verify that the system displays a message indicating 'App recovered, please review your last action'
Step 5: Confirm that the edited task title is now 'Prepare presentation'
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon reopening the application, the user should see a recovery message indicating 'App recovered, please review your last action' and the task titled 'Prepare presentation' should be correctly reflected in the list.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - App Crash Recovery

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Session Timeout Handling During Task Viewing
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system properly handles session timeouts while viewing tasks and ensures user experience continuity.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task list view where multiple tasks are displayed
Step 2: Simulate a session timeout by waiting until the system's idle timeout period (e.g., 30 minutes)
Step 3: Verify that the user is redirected to the login page with a message 'Session expired, please log in again'
Step 4: Log back into the application using valid credentials
Step 5: Confirm that the task list view is accessible and all tasks are still present
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After session timeout, the user should be redirected to the login page with a message 'Session expired, please log in again' and upon successful re-login, the task list view should be fully functional with all previously viewed tasks.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Session Timeout Handling

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Navigation to maximum number of tasks
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system can handle navigation when the user has reached the maximum limit of tasks.
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with exactly 100 tasks
Step 2: Navigate to the task management page
Step 3: Click on the 'Next' button to navigate to the next set of tasks
Step 4: Verify that no new tasks are loaded and an alert message is displayed indicating that there are no more tasks available
Step 5: Attempt to click 'Previous' button and verify that it navigates back to the previous page with all 100 tasks visible
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an alert message stating 'No more tasks available' when navigating beyond the maximum limit of 100 tasks, and clicking 'Previous' button should navigate back to the previous page with all 100 tasks visible.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Navigation from zero tasks
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system correctly handles navigation when there are no tasks.
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with zero tasks
Step 2: Navigate to the task management page
Step 3: Verify that an empty state message is displayed indicating 'No tasks available'
Step 4: Attempt to click both 'Next' and 'Previous' buttons and verify that no navigation occurs and an alert message states 'No more tasks available'
Step 5: Click on the '+' button to add a new task and verify that it navigates to the task creation page
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an empty state message stating 'No tasks available' when there are no tasks, clicking 'Next' or 'Previous' buttons should not navigate and show an alert 'No more tasks available', and clicking '+' button should navigate to the task creation page.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - Navigation from Zero Tasks

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Navigation with single task
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system correctly handles navigation when there is only one task.
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as a user with exactly one task
Step 2: Navigate to the task management page
Step 3: Verify that only one task is displayed and an empty state message is not shown
Step 4: Attempt to click 'Next' button and verify that no new tasks are loaded and an alert message states 'No more tasks available'
Step 5: Click on the '+' button to add a new task and verify that it navigates to the task creation page
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display exactly one task without an empty state message, clicking 'Next' button should not navigate and show an alert 'No more tasks available', and clicking '+' button should navigate to the task creation page.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - Navigation with Single Task

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle navigation to non-existent page
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system gracefully handles attempts to navigate to a non-existent page.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the home page of the task management application
Step 2: Click on the navigation menu and select an invalid or non-existent page link (e.g., '/tasks/nonexistentpage')
Step 3: Observe if a 404 error message is displayed instead of navigating to the non-existent page
Step 4: Verify that the system redirects back to the last known good URL with a clear error message indicating the requested resource was not found
Step 5: Check if the navigation menu remains intact and functional after attempting to navigate to the invalid link
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a clear error message stating that the requested resource was not found, and it should redirect back to the last known good URL with the navigation menu still accessible.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle invalid input in task creation form
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system provides appropriate error messages when users attempt to create tasks with invalid or missing data.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the page where new task creation form is available
Step 2: Leave all mandatory fields (e.g., title) empty and click on 'Create Task'
Step 3: Verify that an error message appears indicating which fields are required
Step 4: Enter a very long string in the title field exceeding the maximum allowed length (e.g., 100 characters)
Step 5: Click 'Create Task' and verify that an error message is displayed stating that the input exceeds the maximum allowed length
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display specific error messages indicating which fields are required or when inputs exceed the maximum allowed length, preventing task creation until valid data is provided.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Handle server-side errors during task deletion
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system provides user-friendly error messages when a server-side issue occurs during task deletion.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the page displaying existing tasks
Step 2: Select a task and initiate the delete action (e.g., clicking 'Delete Task')
Step 3: Simulate or trigger a server-side error during the deletion process by modifying backend settings temporarily
Step 4: Verify that an error message is displayed indicating that there was an issue with deleting the task due to a server-side problem
Step 5: Check if the deleted task remains visible on the page, confirming that it wasn't actually removed from the system
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a clear error message indicating that there was an issue with deleting the task due to a server-side problem, and the deleted task should remain visible on the page.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System maintains 99% uptime under peak load
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system can handle a high number of concurrent users while maintaining 99% uptime.
preconditions: Ensure all system services are running
Clear any existing user sessions and data
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate 500 simultaneous users accessing the login page
Step 2: Monitor system performance metrics for a period of 3 hours
Step 3: Ensure no more than 1% of requests result in server errors or timeouts
Step 4: Verify that all critical system functionalities (e.g., task creation, updates) are available and responsive during the test period
Step 5: Check system logs for any unexpected downtime or service interruptions
Step 6: Confirm that the system recovers fully within 2 minutes after simulated peak load
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should maintain an uptime of at least 99% during the test period, with no more than 1% of requests failing due to server errors or timeouts.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Task creation performance under concurrent user load
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the system's ability to handle task creation requests from multiple users simultaneously without degradation in performance.
preconditions: Ensure all system services are running
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate 200 concurrent users attempting to create new tasks
Step 2: Monitor the time taken for each task creation request from start to finish
Step 3: Ensure that no single task creation takes longer than 5 seconds
Step 4: Verify that all created tasks are correctly stored in the database and visible on the user's dashboard
Step 5: Check system logs for any performance bottlenecks or errors during task creation
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All task creation requests should be completed within 5 seconds, and all tasks must appear correctly on the user's dashboard without any performance degradation.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System response time for task updates under heavy load
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate the system's ability to handle task update requests efficiently when multiple users are active.
preconditions: Ensure all system services are running
Create a baseline set of tasks
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate 300 concurrent users updating existing tasks
Step 2: Monitor the response time for each task update request
Step 3: Ensure that no single task update takes longer than 4 seconds
Step 4: Verify that all updated tasks reflect changes correctly in real-time on the user interface
Step 5: Check system logs for any performance issues or errors during task updates
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All task update requests should be completed within 4 seconds, and all changes must reflect correctly in real-time on the user interface without any performance degradation.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system's ability to handle DDoS attacks without compromising uptime
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can maintain its functionality and availability during a simulated Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack.
preconditions: System is running in production environment
Simulated DDoS traffic generation tool is ready
test_steps: Step 1: Configure the simulated DDoS traffic generator to send HTTP GET requests to /api/status endpoint
Step 2: Set the rate of request generation to 500 requests per second for a duration of 3 minutes
Step 3: Monitor system performance metrics such as CPU and memory usage during the attack simulation
Step 4: Verify that the system maintains an uptime of at least 99% throughout the DDoS attack simulation period
Step 5: Check if any security logs or alerts are triggered due to the detected DDoS activity
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must maintain an uptime of at least 99% during the simulated DDoS attack, and security logs should indicate detection of potential malicious activity.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate system's response to SQL injection attempts on critical endpoints
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system is protected against SQL injection attacks targeting specific API endpoints.
test_steps: Step 1: Craft a malicious payload for an SQL injection attempt, such as ' OR '1'='1
Step 2: Send the crafted payload in the query parameter of the GET request to /api/users?id=1
Step 3: Observe if there is any unexpected data returned or system behavior change due to the injected SQL code
Step 4: Check the server-side logs for any security-related warnings or errors indicating an attempted attack
Step 5: Confirm that no sensitive information is exposed and the response status code indicates a failure (e.g., HTTP 400)
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must not return any unexpected data or expose sensitive information, and should respond with an appropriate error status code indicating that the request was invalid.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Test system's resilience against XSS attacks on user input fields
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system is secure from Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) by validating and sanitizing user inputs.
test_steps: Step 1: Prepare a JavaScript injection payload such as '<script>alert('XSS')</script>'
Step 2: Enter the payload into the 'username' field of the user registration form and submit it
Step 3: Observe if any pop-up alert or other script execution occurs on the page after submission
Step 4: Check server-side logs for any security warnings related to suspicious input patterns
Step 5: Verify that the submitted data is stored in a sanitized format without executing any scripts
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must prevent the execution of injected JavaScript code and store user inputs securely, ensuring no pop-ups or script executions occur.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system maintain 99% uptime UI element clarity and placement
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the user interface elements related to monitoring system uptime are clear, well-placed, and easily accessible.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the system status page from the main navigation menu
Step 2: Identify the 'Uptime Status' widget on the dashboard
Step 3: Verify that the widget displays a clear percentage value indicating current uptime (e.g., 99%)
Step 4: Check if the widget is located in a prominent position on the dashboard, such as near the top or center of the page
Step 5: Ensure that there are no overlapping elements or distractions around the 'Uptime Status' widget
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The 'Uptime Status' widget is clearly visible and prominently placed on the dashboard without any overlapping elements, displaying a clear percentage value indicating current uptime.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task completion time for checking system uptime status
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that users can quickly check the current system uptime status without delay.
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the system status page from the main navigation menu
Step 2: Identify and click on the 'Uptime Status' widget or equivalent link/button
Step 3: Measure the time taken for the system to display the current uptime percentage value after clicking the widget/link
Step 4: Ensure that the displayed uptime percentage is updated within 1 second of interaction
Step 5: Verify that no additional loading indicators are present, indicating immediate availability of data
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system displays the current uptime percentage value immediately upon clicking the 'Uptime Status' widget or equivalent link/button, with a maximum delay of 1 second and without any additional loading indicators.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify error message clarity when system uptime drops below threshold
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that users receive clear and understandable error messages if the system's uptime falls below the specified threshold.
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate a scenario where the system uptime drops to 98%
Step 2: Navigate to the system status page from the main navigation menu
Step 3: Identify and click on the 'Uptime Status' widget or equivalent link/button
Step 4: Verify that an error message is displayed indicating that the system uptime has dropped below the threshold of 99%
Step 5: Ensure that the error message provides clear instructions for users to take appropriate actions, such as contacting support
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: An error message is clearly displayed when the system's uptime drops below 99%, indicating a critical status and providing specific guidance on how to proceed.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system maintain 99% uptime on iOS and Android devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system maintains 99% uptime across different mobile operating systems.
preconditions: System is installed on both iOS and Android devices
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the application on an iPhone running iOS 15.0
Step 2: Navigate to the main dashboard page and observe system status for 3 hours
Step 3: Repeat Step 2 on a Samsung Galaxy S21 running Android 12.0
Step 4: Monitor network logs during testing period for any disconnections or errors
Step 5: Calculate uptime percentage based on observed data and compare with the requirement of 99% uptime
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must maintain an uptime percentage greater than or equal to 99% on both iOS and Android devices over a continuous observation period of at least 3 hours.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system maintain 99% uptime on different screen sizes and resolutions
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system maintains 99% uptime across various screen sizes and resolutions.
preconditions: System is installed on devices with varying screen sizes and resolutions
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the application on a MacBook Pro with Retina display (resolution: 2560x1600)
Step 2: Navigate to the main dashboard page and observe system status for 3 hours
Step 3: Repeat Step 2 on an iPad Air (2nd generation) with resolution of 2048x1536
Step 4: Monitor network logs during testing period for any disconnections or errors
Step 5: Calculate uptime percentage based on observed data and compare with the requirement of 99% uptime
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must maintain an uptime percentage greater than or equal to 99% on devices with screen resolutions of 2560x1600 and 2048x1536 over a continuous observation period of at least 3 hours.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system maintain 99% uptime on different network types (WiFi, 4G, 5G)
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system maintains 99% uptime across various network types.
preconditions: System is installed on devices with WiFi and cellular data capabilities
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the application on a device connected to a stable WiFi network
Step 2: Navigate to the main dashboard page and observe system status for 3 hours
Step 3: Switch the device's network connection to 4G LTE and repeat Step 2
Step 4: Switch the device's network connection to 5G and repeat Step 2
Step 5: Monitor network logs during testing period for any disconnections or errors
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must maintain an uptime percentage greater than or equal to 99% on devices connected via WiFi, 4G LTE, and 5G networks over a continuous observation period of at least 3 hours.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify successful creation of a new todo item
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that a new todo item can be created successfully via the API and meets all validation criteria.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
User has permission to create todos
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/todos with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 2: Include request body: {"title": "Buy groceries", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 4: Verify response body contains created todo with auto-generated ID and title 'Buy groceries'
Step 5: Verify response body includes 'createdAt' timestamp in ISO format
Step 6: Verify that the newly created todo item appears in GET /api/todos response
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API should return a 201 status code with the newly created todo item containing an auto-generated ID, title 'Buy groceries', and a 'createdAt' timestamp in ISO format.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify deletion of an existing todo item
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that a specific todo item can be deleted successfully via the API.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
User has permission to delete todos
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos to retrieve all existing todo items
Step 2: Identify a specific todo item ID from the response
Step 3: Send DELETE request to /api/todos/{todo_id} with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify HTTP 204 status code returned indicating successful deletion
Step 5: Send GET request to /api/todos again and verify that the deleted todo item is no longer present in the response
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The API should return a 204 status code upon successful deletion of the specified todo item, and subsequent GET requests to /api/todos should not include this deleted item.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify rate limiting on API requests
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system enforces a maximum of 100 requests per minute for authenticated users to prevent abuse.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos and verify successful response
Step 2: Repeat sending POST requests to /api/todos with different titles, each time verifying a 201 status code
Step 3: After the 99th request, send another POST request and expect HTTP 429 Too Many Requests status code
Step 4: Wait for 60 seconds and then attempt to send another POST request; verify successful response with 201 status code
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should allow up to 99 POST requests within a minute and then return HTTP 429 Too Many Requests status code for the 100th request, with subsequent successful responses after waiting for one minute.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate CRUD operations for task management system
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that all CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations maintain data integrity and consistency within the task management system.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Create Task", "description": "This is a test task", "completed": false}
Step 2: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned
Step 3: Send GET request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token>
Step 4: Verify that the newly created task appears in the response and its 'title' is "Create Task"
Step 5: Update the task by sending PUT request to /api/tasks/<task_id> with body {"completed": true}
Step 6: Send GET request again to verify the updated status of the task
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return a HTTP 201 status code upon creation, and the newly created task with title 'Create Task' should be present in subsequent GET requests. After updating the task to completed state, the GET request must reflect this change.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate mandatory and optional field constraints during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system enforces data integrity by validating both mandatory and optional fields when creating a new task.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Attempt to create a task without providing 'title' field, sending POST request to /api/tasks with body {"description": "Test description", "completed": false}
Step 2: Verify that the system returns HTTP 400 status code and an error message indicating missing mandatory fields

Step 3: Create a task successfully by providing all required fields, sending POST request to /api/tasks with body {"title": "Test Task", "description": "This is a test description", "completed": false}
Step 4: Verify HTTP 201 status code and the presence of 'title' field in response
Step 5: Attempt to create another task without providing optional 'description' field, sending POST request with body {"title": "Another Test Task", "completed": false}
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return HTTP 400 status code and an error message for missing 'title' field. Upon providing all required fields, a task is created successfully with HTTP 201 status code. Creating a task without optional 'description' field should succeed.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate transaction integrity during concurrent task creation and deletion
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system maintains data consistency when performing multiple CRUD operations concurrently.
preconditions: User is authenticated with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Simultaneously send two POST requests to /api/tasks, one with body {"title": "Task A", "completed": false} and another with body {"title": "Task B", "completed": false}
Step 2: Verify that both tasks are created successfully with HTTP 201 status code
Step 3: Immediately send DELETE request to /api/tasks/<task_id_A> for Task A
Step 4: Send GET request to /api/tasks and verify that only Task B is present in the response
Step 5: Simultaneously attempt to create a new task while deleting an existing one, sending POST and DELETE requests concurrently
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should maintain data consistency by ensuring that only the intended tasks are created or deleted. After deleting Task A, GET request must return only Task B in response.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During Task Creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system maintains task creation functionality after a network interruption.
test_steps: Step 1: User initiates task creation by clicking 'Add New Task' button
Step 2: Before the request is sent, disconnect internet connection
Step 3: Reconnect internet and send POST request to /api/tasks with valid JWT token in header
Step 4: Verify HTTP 201 status code returned after reconnection
Step 5: Verify task appears in GET /api/tasks response
Step 6: Ensure UI displays success message for task creation
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system successfully recovers from network interruption and creates the task with a status code of 201, displaying a success message on the UI.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery During Task Editing
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system retains task editing progress after an app crash.
test_steps: Step 1: User starts editing a task by clicking 'Edit' button on a specific task
Step 2: Modify task title to 'Finalize project report'
Step 3: Force app crash using Android command 'adb shell am broadcast -a android.intent.action.CLEAR_TOP'
Step 4: Reopen the app and navigate back to the editing page of the same task
Step 5: Verify that the modified title 'Finalize project report' is still displayed in the edit field
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After a forced app crash, the system retains the user's editing progress and displays the modified task title 'Finalize project report' in the edit field.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Session Timeout Handling After GPS Signal Loss
phase2_test_cases.description: Test that the system maintains session integrity after a period of inactivity and subsequent GPS signal loss.
test_steps: Step 1: User logs into the application with active GPS location services
Step 2: Wait for 30 minutes to trigger session timeout due to inactivity
Step 3: Temporarily disable GPS signal on device
Step 4: Attempt to navigate back to task management page
Step 5: Verify that the system prompts user to re-authenticate before accessing tasks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Following a session timeout due to inactivity and subsequent GPS signal loss, the system requires re-authentication from the user before allowing access to task management features.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System maintain 99% uptime - Boundary Test for Maximum Downtime Permitted
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system does not exceed a maximum downtime of 0.1% over any given year to ensure 99.9% uptime.
test_steps: Step 1: Initiate monitoring session for a full calendar year
Step 2: Record total downtime in seconds during the monitored period
Step 3: Calculate maximum allowable downtime as 0.1% of 8760 hours (total hours in a year)
Step 4: Compare recorded downtime against calculated allowable downtime
Step 5: Assert that recorded downtime is less than or equal to 28 minutes and 12 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system's recorded downtime over the year must not exceed 0.1% of total operational hours, ensuring an uptime of at least 99.9%. The test will pass if the recorded downtime is less than or equal to 345.6 seconds.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System maintain 99% uptime - Boundary Test for Daily Downtime Limit
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system does not exceed a daily downtime limit to meet the annual 99.9% uptime requirement.
preconditions: Monitoring tools are set up with daily reporting
test_steps: Step 1: Start monitoring at the beginning of each day
Step 2: Record downtime in seconds for each hour throughout the day
Step 3: Calculate maximum allowable daily downtime as 0.04% of 24 hours (total hours in a day)
Step 4: Sum up all recorded downtimes to get total daily downtime
Step 5: Assert that total daily downtime is less than or equal to 57.6 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system's daily downtime must not exceed 0.04% of total operational hours in a day to ensure an uptime of at least 99.9%. The test will pass if the recorded downtime is less than or equal to 57.6 seconds.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System maintain 99% uptime - Boundary Test for Weekly Downtime Limit
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system does not exceed a weekly downtime limit to meet the annual 99.9% uptime requirement.
preconditions: Monitoring tools are set up with weekly reporting
test_steps: Step 1: Start monitoring at the beginning of each week
Step 2: Record downtime in seconds for each day throughout the week
Step 3: Calculate maximum allowable weekly downtime as 0.28% of 168 hours (total hours in a week)
Step 4: Sum up all recorded downtimes to get total weekly downtime
Step 5: Assert that total weekly downtime is less than or equal to 475.2 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system's weekly downtime must not exceed 0.28% of total operational hours in a week to ensure an uptime of at least 99.9%. The test will pass if the recorded downtime is less than or equal to 475.2 seconds.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System maintains uptime during unexpected database connection loss
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system can handle unexpected disconnections from the database and maintain at least 99% uptime.
preconditions: System is operational with active user sessions
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate a sudden disconnect between the application server and the database by stopping the database service
Step 2: Attempt to create a new task via the 'Add Task' page on the system's UI
Step 3: Verify that the system displays an error message indicating a temporary issue with saving the task
Step 4: Wait for 5 minutes and restart the database service
Step 5: Check if all user sessions remain active and no data loss has occurred
Step 6: Confirm that any tasks attempted during the downtime are automatically saved once the connection is restored
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a user-friendly error message and maintain at least 99% uptime over a period of one hour, with all pending tasks saved once the database connection is restored.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System handles unexpected API endpoint failure gracefully
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can handle failures in external API endpoints without impacting overall uptime.
preconditions: System is running with active user sessions
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate an outage for a critical external API by blocking its endpoint
Step 2: Attempt to perform an action that relies on the external API, such as syncing tasks from another system
Step 3: Verify that the system logs an error indicating the failure of the external API call
Step 4: Check if the system displays a message informing users about the temporary unavailability of the feature
Step 5: Wait for 10 minutes and ensure that no user sessions are affected by the outage
Step 6: Confirm that once the API is back online, all pending actions are automatically processed
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should log an error and display a user-friendly message about temporary unavailability of the sync tasks feature. The system must maintain at least 99% uptime during this period, with all pending actions processed once the API is restored.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: System recovers from unexpected server crashes while maintaining task integrity
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can recover from sudden server crashes without losing any user data.
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate a sudden server crash by stopping the application server process
Step 2: Wait for 30 minutes to allow all pending tasks and updates to be saved in the database
Step 3: Restart the application server and verify that it starts without errors
Step 4: Check if all user sessions are restored upon server restart
Step 5: Verify that no data loss has occurred for any active or pending tasks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should recover from a server crash within 30 minutes and maintain at least 99% uptime. All user sessions must be restored, and no data loss should occur for any active or pending tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system performance when adding tasks across major browsers
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the task management system maintains optimal performance while users add new tasks in Chrome, Firefox, and Safari.
preconditions: System is running on a server with at least 8GB RAM
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management page in Google Chrome
Step 2: Click on 'Add Task' button and enter task details including title, description, due date (set for tomorrow), and priority level (High)
Step 3: Repeat Step 2 for Firefox and Safari browsers, ensuring consistent data entry across all three browsers
Step 4: Measure the time taken to add each task in Chrome using performance monitoring tools like Lighthouse or WebPageTest
Step 5: Verify that the added tasks appear correctly on the 'My Tasks' page within 2 seconds of submission for all tested browsers
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should add the task within 2 seconds and display it correctly on the 'My Tasks' page in all three major browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari) with no performance degradation or errors.

test_data.description: Create detailed slides for tomorrow's meeting

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Evaluate system responsiveness when filtering tasks by priority level in Chrome
phase2_test_cases.description: Test the performance of the task management system's filtering feature to ensure quick response times when users filter tasks based on priority levels.
preconditions: System is running and user logged in
Multiple tasks with varying priorities exist in the database
test_steps: Step 1: Open Google Chrome and log into the task management application
Step 2: Navigate to the 'My Tasks' page where all tasks are listed
Step 3: Click on the filter dropdown menu and select 'High Priority'
Step 4: Measure the time taken for the system to display only high-priority tasks using performance monitoring tools
Step 5: Verify that the filtered list of high-priority tasks is displayed within 1 second
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should filter and display only high-priority tasks within 1 second when using the filtering feature in Google Chrome, ensuring a smooth user experience.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Test system performance under concurrent task creation by multiple users in Chrome
phase2_test_cases.description: Simulate a scenario where multiple users simultaneously create tasks to evaluate the system's ability to handle high concurrency and maintain responsiveness.
preconditions: System is running on a server capable of handling load testing
test_steps: Step 1: Set up a load testing environment with at least 50 users using tools like JMeter or LoadRunner
Step 2: Configure each user to log into the task management system in Google Chrome
Step 3: Simulate simultaneous creation of tasks by all users, ensuring each task has unique details (title, description, due date)
Step 4: Monitor the server's CPU and memory usage during the load test using tools like New Relic or Datadog
Step 5: Verify that the system can handle up to 50 simultaneous task creations without significant performance degradation
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should be able to handle up to 50 simultaneous users creating tasks in Google Chrome without any significant performance issues, ensuring that all tasks are successfully added and displayed within an acceptable timeframe.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Attack Prevention in Task Management System
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system prevents XSS attacks when users input malicious scripts through various fields.
preconditions: User is logged into the system
Browser console is open for monitoring
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Add Task' page in Chrome browser
Step 2: Enter a task title containing a script tag with an alert function, e.g., '<script>alert('XSS')</script>'
Step 3: Submit the form without including any other details
Step 4: Verify that no JavaScript alert is triggered and the input is sanitized or rejected by the system
Step 5: Check browser console for any error messages related to script execution
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should prevent the input of malicious scripts, ensuring that no JavaScript alert is triggered and the input is sanitized or rejected.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: SQL Injection Attack Prevention in Task Management System
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system prevents SQL injection attacks when users input malicious data through search or filter fields.
preconditions: User is logged into the system
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Task Search' page in Chrome browser
Step 2: Enter a search query containing SQL injection payload, e.g., ' OR '1'='1'
Step 3: Submit the form without including any other details
Step 4: Verify that no database errors are logged and the system returns an appropriate error message or sanitized result
Step 5: Check database logs for any suspicious SQL queries
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should prevent the execution of malicious SQL commands, ensuring that no database errors are logged and an appropriate error message is displayed.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection in Task Management System
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system protects against CSRF attacks by validating request tokens.
preconditions: User is logged into the system
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the 'Add Task' page in Chrome browser
Step 2: Open Developer Tools and intercept a POST request for task creation
Step 3: Modify the intercepted request by removing or altering the CSRF token
Step 4: Resend the modified request and verify that it is rejected with an appropriate error message
Step 5: Check network requests to confirm that no unauthorized tasks are created
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should reject any POST request for task creation if the CSRF token is missing or invalid, ensuring that no unauthorized tasks are created.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: 3.4 Security Requirements - Cross-Site Request Forgery Prevention

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify UI element clarity and placement for task creation in Chrome browser
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the 'Create Task' button is clearly visible and placed appropriately on the main dashboard page.
test_steps: Step 1: Open the application's main dashboard page in Google Chrome
Step 2: Scroll through the page to locate the 'Create Task' button
Step 3: Verify that the 'Create Task' button is located at the top right corner of the dashboard
Step 4: Hover over the 'Create Task' button and ensure it changes color or highlights, indicating interactivity
Step 5: Click on the 'Create Task' button to open the task creation form
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The 'Create Task' button is clearly visible at the top right corner of the dashboard in Google Chrome and changes color or highlights when hovered over.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task completion time for adding a new task in Chrome browser
phase2_test_cases.description: Measure the time it takes to add a new task from start to finish, ensuring that the process is efficient and quick.
test_steps: Step 1: Open the application's main dashboard page in Google Chrome
Step 2: Click on the 'Create Task' button to open the task creation form
Step 3: Enter a title for the new task and set any required fields (e.g., due date, priority level)
Step 4: Click 'Save' or 'Submit' to add the new task to the system
Step 5: Verify that the newly created task appears in the list of tasks on the dashboard
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The process of adding a new task from clicking the 'Create Task' button to seeing it appear on the dashboard should take no more than 10 seconds.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify error message clarity when adding a duplicate task in Chrome browser
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system provides clear and informative error messages when attempting to add a task with an existing title.
test_steps: Step 1: Open the application's main dashboard page in Google Chrome
Step 2: Click on the 'Create Task' button to open the task creation form
Step 3: Enter a title for an existing task and set any required fields (e.g., due date, priority level)
Step 4: Click 'Save' or 'Submit' to attempt adding the duplicate task
Step 5: Verify that an error message is displayed indicating that the task already exists
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: When attempting to add a duplicate task, the system should display an error message stating 'Task with this title already exists.' within 2 seconds of clicking 'Save' or 'Submit'.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task management system functionality across Chrome, Firefox, and Safari browsers
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system functions correctly on major web browsers without any layout or functional issues.
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task management system in Google Chrome browser and log in using a valid user account
Step 2: Navigate to the 'Tasks' page and verify that all UI elements are displayed correctly (buttons, text fields, list items)
Step 3: Create a new task by clicking on the 'Add Task' button and entering details such as title and due date
Step 4: Repeat steps 1-3 for Mozilla Firefox browser and then Safari browser to ensure consistent functionality across all three browsers
Step 5: Verify that all tasks created in Chrome are also visible in Firefox and Safari, and vice versa, with no data loss or corruption
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should display all UI elements correctly and allow users to create, view, and manage tasks without any layout or functional issues across Chrome, Firefox, and Safari browsers.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: System ensure that the system function across major browsers chrome

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task management system functionality on different screen sizes and resolutions
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system is responsive and functions correctly on various screen sizes and resolutions.
test_steps: Step 1: Open the task management system in Google Chrome browser and log in using a valid user account
Step 2: Adjust the browser window size to emulate a mobile device (e.g., iPhone X - 375x812 pixels)
Step 3: Verify that all UI elements are displayed responsively without any overlapping or missing content
Step 4: Repeat steps 1-3 for different screen resolutions such as desktop resolution (1920x1080) and tablet resolution (768x1024)
Step 5: Create a new task on the mobile version of the system, then verify that it is also visible in the desktop version with all details intact
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should display all UI elements responsively and allow users to create, view, and manage tasks without any layout or functional issues across different screen sizes and resolutions.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: System ensure that the system function across major browsers chrome

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task management system functionality with varying network types (WiFi, 4G, 5G)
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system functions correctly under different network conditions.
test_steps: Step 1: Connect to a WiFi network and open the task management system in Google Chrome browser
Step 2: Log in using a valid user account and navigate to the 'Tasks' page, verifying that all tasks load within 3 seconds
Step 3: Switch to a 4G mobile data connection and repeat steps 1-2, ensuring that task loading time does not exceed 5 seconds
Step 4: Connect to a 5G network and repeat the login process, checking for any delays or performance issues compared to WiFi and 4G connections
Step 5: Create a new task on each network type (WiFi, 4G, 5G) and verify that it is successfully added to the system within respective time limits
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should load all tasks and allow users to create new tasks within the specified time limits (WiFi: 3 seconds, 4G: 5 seconds) under different network conditions without any performance degradation.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: System ensure that the system function across major browsers chrome

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure API functions across major browsers - Chrome
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system's API endpoints function correctly when accessed via Google Chrome browser.
preconditions: User is authenticated with a valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos using cURL command in Chrome Developer Tools
Step 2: Include Authorization header with value 'Bearer <valid_jwt_token>'
Step 3: Verify HTTP status code 200 is returned indicating successful response
Step 4: Check that the response body contains an array of todos, each with fields id (integer), title (string), completed (boolean)
Step 5: Ensure 'createdAt' timestamp exists for each todo item in the response
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The GET request to /api/todos returns HTTP status code 200 and the response body includes an array of todos with valid fields id, title, completed, and createdAt timestamps.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify API rate limiting in Chrome browser
phase2_test_cases.description: Test if the system's API enforces rate limiting when accessed via Google Chrome.
preconditions: User is authenticated with a valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos using cURL command in Chrome Developer Tools
Step 2: Include Authorization header with value 'Bearer <valid_jwt_token>'
Step 3: Repeat the same GET request immediately after receiving a successful response
Step 4: Verify that subsequent requests return HTTP status code 429 indicating too many requests
Step 5: Wait for rate limit reset period and verify that another request returns HTTP status code 200
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After sending multiple GET requests to /api/todos within a short time frame, the system returns HTTP status code 429 indicating rate limiting is enforced. Once the rate limit resets, another request should return HTTP status code 200.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate API response time in Chrome browser
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system's API responses are within acceptable time limits when accessed via Google Chrome.
preconditions: User is authenticated with a valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Send GET request to /api/todos using cURL command in Chrome Developer Tools
Step 2: Include Authorization header with value 'Bearer <valid_jwt_token>'
Step 3: Measure the time taken for the response from sending the request until receiving a complete response body
Step 4: Verify that the total response time is less than or equal to 2 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The GET request to /api/todos returns a complete response body within 2 seconds or less.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure data consistency after CRUD operations on task management system
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system maintains data integrity and consistency across various CRUD operations.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid credentials
Task management system UI is accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Management page and ensure it loads without errors
Step 2: Click on 'Add New Task' button, enter task title as 'Test Task', set status to 'Incomplete'
Step 3: Submit the new task form. Verify that the system returns a unique ID for the newly created task
Step 4: Edit the task by clicking on its edit icon and change the title to 'Updated Test Task'. Ensure the update is reflected in real-time without any delay
Step 5: Delete the updated task via the delete button. Confirm that the task no longer appears in the list of tasks
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should maintain data integrity by ensuring that CRUD operations are accurately reflected without any discrepancies or delays.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate mandatory vs optional field integrity during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system correctly handles mandatory and optional fields when creating a new task.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid credentials
Task management system UI is accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Management page and click on 'Add New Task'
Step 2: Leave the title field empty, set status to 'Incomplete', and submit
Step 3: Verify that an error message appears indicating that the task title is a mandatory field
Step 4: Enter a valid task title, leave the description field (optional) blank, and submit
Step 5: Confirm that the system accepts the new task without any issues despite the missing optional fields
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display an error message for missing mandatory fields but allow submission with optional fields left blank.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure data type constraints are enforced during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system enforces proper data types for fields such as title (string), status (boolean), and due date (date).
preconditions: User is logged in with valid credentials
Task management system UI is accessible
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the Task Management page and click on 'Add New Task'
Step 2: Enter a title using special characters (!@#$%^&*)
Step 3: Set status as 'Incomplete' (boolean)
Step 4: Input an invalid date format for due date, e.g., '15/07/2023'
Step 5: Submit the task and verify that an error message appears indicating incorrect data type or format
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should reject the task submission and display error messages for invalid data types or formats.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During Task Creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the system can recover gracefully from a network interruption during task creation.
preconditions: User is logged in and on the task creation page
test_steps: Step 1: Start creating a new task by entering 'Buy groceries' as the title
Step 2: Simulate a network interruption (e.g., turn off Wi-Fi or cellular data)
Step 3: Attempt to save the task and observe if the system displays an error message indicating a network issue
Step 4: Re-establish internet connection and retry saving the task
Step 5: Verify that the task is successfully saved after reconnection, with no loss of entered data
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a clear error message during network interruption and allow the user to retry saving the task without losing any inputted data.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery During Task Editing
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system can recover from an app crash while editing a task.
preconditions: User is logged in and on the task editing page
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task editing page for Task ID 12345
Step 2: Modify the title of the task to 'Buy groceries'
Step 3: Force close or crash the application (e.g., using Android's Developer Options -> Don't keep activities)
Step 4: Restart the app and navigate back to the task editing page for Task ID 12345
Step 5: Verify that the modified title 'Buy groceries' is still present in the task editor
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should retain any unsaved changes made to a task before an app crash and allow users to continue editing without data loss.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Session Timeout Handling After Network Interruption
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system handles session timeouts correctly after a network interruption.
preconditions: User is logged in and active
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate a network interruption (e.g., turn off Wi-Fi or cellular data)
Step 2: Wait for the session timeout period to elapse (typically around 30 minutes)
Step 3: Re-establish internet connection and attempt to perform any action requiring authentication
Step 4: Verify that the system redirects the user to the login page with a message indicating session expiration
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After re-establishing internet connection, the system should redirect the user to the login page and display an appropriate session timeout message.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure task management system functions on Chrome browser minimum version
phase2_test_cases.description: Verify that the task management system operates correctly in the minimum supported version of Google Chrome.
preconditions: Install and launch Google Chrome version 80.0.3987.145
Log in to the task management system with a valid user account
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management system's homepage using the installed minimum supported version of Chrome
Step 2: Click on the 'Tasks' tab from the navigation menu and observe if all tasks are displayed without any layout issues or errors
Step 3: Attempt to create a new task by clicking the '+' button, entering a title ('Test Task'), and setting the status to 'Incomplete'
Step 4: Verify that the newly created task appears in the list of tasks with correct details and no JavaScript errors are logged in the browser console
