Step 5: Attempt to filter tasks by selecting 'Completed' from the dropdown menu above the task list, ensuring all completed tasks are displayed without any performance issues
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should function correctly in the minimum supported version of Google Chrome, displaying all tasks without layout or performance issues and allowing for new task creation and filtering.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify task management system's functionality on Chrome browser maximum version
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system operates correctly in the latest supported version of Google Chrome.
preconditions: Install and launch the latest supported version of Google Chrome
Log in to the task management system with a valid user account
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management system's homepage using the installed maximum supported version of Chrome
Step 2: Click on the 'Tasks' tab from the navigation menu and observe if all tasks are displayed without any layout issues or errors
Step 3: Attempt to create a new task by clicking the '+' button, entering a title ('Test Task'), and setting the status to 'Incomplete'
Step 4: Verify that the newly created task appears in the list of tasks with correct details and no JavaScript errors are logged in the browser console
Step 5: Attempt to filter tasks by selecting 'Completed' from the dropdown menu above the task list, ensuring all completed tasks are displayed without any performance issues
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should function correctly in the latest supported version of Google Chrome, displaying all tasks without layout or performance issues and allowing for new task creation and filtering.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Check task management system's responsiveness on Chrome browser with maximum number of tasks
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the task management system can handle a large number of tasks without performance degradation in Google Chrome.
preconditions: Install and launch any supported version of Google Chrome
Log in to the task management system with a valid user account
test_steps: Step 1: Create 500 new tasks by clicking the '+' button repeatedly, entering titles ('Test Task') and setting statuses randomly
Step 2: Click on the 'Tasks' tab from the navigation menu and observe if all tasks are displayed without any layout issues or delays in loading time
Step 3: Attempt to filter tasks by selecting 'Incomplete' from the dropdown menu above the task list, ensuring only incomplete tasks are displayed within a reasonable timeframe
Step 4: Verify that sorting tasks by clicking on the 'Due Date' column header arranges all tasks correctly without any performance issues or delays
Step 5: Attempt to delete several tasks in bulk and observe if the system updates the task list immediately with correct counts
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task management system should handle up to 500 tasks without performance degradation, displaying all tasks correctly and allowing for filtering and sorting within a reasonable timeframe.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management System Performance Under Load

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles unexpected browser behavior in Chrome
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the task management system gracefully handles errors when an unexpected event occurs during user interaction in Chrome.
preconditions: User is logged into the system
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management dashboard page
Step 2: Simulate a network interruption while attempting to add a new task via the 'Add Task' button
Step 3: Observe and record any error messages displayed on the screen
Step 4: Verify that the system displays a user-friendly message indicating an issue with connectivity or server response time
Step 5: Ensure that after reconnecting, previously unsaved task data is not lost and can be recovered upon successful reconnection
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a clear error message indicating network issues, and upon reconnection, the task management page should reload with all previously entered data intact.

test_data.task_title: Test Task for Network Error Handling

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate system response to JavaScript errors in Chrome
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the task management system can handle unexpected JavaScript errors and provide a seamless user experience.
preconditions: User is logged into the system
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management dashboard page
Step 2: Introduce an intentional JavaScript error in the console by executing a script that triggers an unhandled exception
Step 3: Observe and record any error messages displayed on the screen or in the developer tools console
Step 4: Verify that the system does not crash but instead logs the error and displays a user-friendly message indicating an internal issue
Step 5: Confirm that after logging out and logging back in, all tasks are still visible and functional
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should log the JavaScript error without crashing, display a user-friendly message indicating an internal issue, and maintain all task data integrity upon re-login.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Check system's ability to recover from database connection loss in Chrome
phase2_test_cases.description: Test the task management system's resilience by simulating a temporary loss of database connectivity and verifying recovery behavior.
preconditions: User is logged into the system
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the task management dashboard page
Step 2: Simulate a database connection loss by temporarily disabling network access to the server hosting the database
Step 3: Attempt to add a new task via the 'Add Task' button while the connection is lost and observe any error messages displayed on the screen
Step 4: Verify that the system displays an appropriate message indicating a temporary issue with data storage
Step 5: Re-enable network access, log out and back in, then verify that all tasks are still visible and functional
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should display a message indicating temporary data storage issues, recover upon re-establishing network connection, and ensure task visibility and functionality post-recovery.

test_data.task_title: Test Task for Database Connection Loss

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Backend Service handles up to 100 concurrent users for CRUD operations
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the backend service can handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on tasks without performance degradation.
preconditions: Valid JWT tokens are available for all users
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate login of 100 concurrent users using valid JWT tokens
Step 2: Each user sends a POST request to /api/tasks with task details (title, description)
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code for each create operation and ensure tasks are stored correctly in the database
Step 4: Simulate read operations by sending GET requests from all users to retrieve their created tasks within a time limit of 5 seconds per request
Step 5: Each user updates one task using PUT request with updated details, verify HTTP 200 status code and task update in the database
Step 6: Simulate delete operations by sending DELETE requests from all users to remove their tasks within a time limit of 3 seconds per request
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks without performance degradation, ensuring all requests are processed within the specified time limits and task data is correctly updated in the database.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Backend Service handles concurrent user creation of tasks with maximum limit validation
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the backend service can handle up to 100 concurrent users creating tasks and ensures no more than 100 tasks are created simultaneously.
preconditions: Valid JWT tokens for all users
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate login of 100 concurrent users using valid JWT tokens
Step 2: Each user sends a POST request to /api/tasks with task details (title, description)
Step 3: Verify HTTP 201 status code for each create operation and ensure tasks are stored correctly in the database
Step 4: Monitor system response time during concurrent task creation ensuring it does not exceed 5 seconds per user
Step 5: Attempt to add an additional task by a new user, verify HTTP 429 Too Many Requests status code indicating rate limiting
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle up to 100 concurrent users creating tasks simultaneously without performance degradation, ensuring task creation is limited to a maximum of 100 tasks and any additional requests are rate-limited.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Backend Service handles concurrent user updates of existing tasks with performance validation
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the backend service can handle up to 100 concurrent users updating existing tasks without performance degradation.
preconditions: Valid JWT tokens for all users
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate login of 100 concurrent users using valid JWT tokens
Step 2: Each user sends a GET request to /api/tasks to retrieve an existing task ID
Step 3: Each user updates the retrieved task using PUT request with updated details, verify HTTP 200 status code and task update in the database
Step 4: Monitor system response time during concurrent task updates ensuring it does not exceed 5 seconds per user
Step 5: Verify that all tasks are correctly updated in the database after the update operations
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle up to 100 concurrent users updating existing tasks simultaneously without performance degradation, ensuring task updates are processed within the specified time limits and all tasks are correctly updated in the database.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure backend service handles up to 100 concurrent users without data corruption
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system can handle up to 100 concurrent user connections and perform CRUD operations on tasks without causing data inconsistencies or errors.
preconditions: System is running in a test environment
At least 100 valid user tokens are available
test_steps: Step 1: Create 100 unique user sessions with POST /api/users endpoint using distinct email addresses and passwords
Step 2: For each session, send simultaneous GET requests to /api/tasks to ensure all users can retrieve their task lists without errors
Step 3: Simultaneously for each session, send PUT requests updating a single task's 'completed' status from false to true across all sessions
Step 4: Verify that the system responds with HTTP 200 OK for all update requests and no data corruption occurs in any user’s task list
Step 5: Send GET /api/tasks requests again to confirm that the updated statuses are reflected correctly without duplicates or missing entries
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should successfully handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks, with all updates reflected accurately in each user's task list without data corruption or inconsistencies.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Backend Service Scalability

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Prevent unauthorized access to user-specific task CRUD operations
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users can perform CRUD operations on their own tasks, preventing unauthorized access or data tampering.
preconditions: System is running in a test environment
At least 2 valid user tokens are available
test_steps: Step 1: Authenticate two different users using POST /api/login with distinct credentials
Step 2: Retrieve task IDs for both users by sending GET requests to /api/tasks
Step 3: Attempt to update a task belonging to User A from the session of User B via PUT request to /api/tasks/{task_id}
Step 4: Verify that the system responds with HTTP 401 Unauthorized or similar error indicating lack of permission for this operation
Step 5: Confirm that attempting to delete a task owned by User A from User B's session results in an appropriate access denied response
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must return HTTP 401 Unauthorized or a similar error message when an unauthorized user attempts to modify or delete another user's task, ensuring data integrity and security.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Security & Authentication

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate rate limiting on concurrent CRUD operations to prevent abuse
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system implements effective rate limiting mechanisms to restrict excessive or abusive CRUD operations by any single user, maintaining system stability and security.
preconditions: System is running in a test environment
At least 1 valid user token is available
test_steps: Step 1: Authenticate a user using POST /api/login with valid credentials
Step 2: Send rapid consecutive PUT requests to update the same task's 'completed' status from false to true and back multiple times within seconds
Step 3: Monitor system responses for rate limiting enforcement, expecting HTTP 429 Too Many Requests after reaching a predefined limit
Step 4: Confirm that subsequent attempts to perform CRUD operations are delayed or blocked until the rate limit resets
Step 5: Verify that no data inconsistencies occur due to rapid updates being restricted by rate limiting
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must enforce a rate limit on CRUD operations, returning HTTP 429 Too Many Requests after the threshold is exceeded and preventing further updates until the rate limit resets.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Security & Performance

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify UI element clarity and placement for task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the UI elements for creating a new task are clearly visible, intuitively placed, and easy to interact with.
preconditions: User navigates to task management page
test_steps: Step 1: User clicks on the 'Add Task' button located at the top right corner of the task list
Step 2: A modal or pop-up form appears with fields for 'Title', 'Description', and 'Due Date'
Step 3: The user enters a title in the 'Title' field, ensuring it is less than 100 characters as per system constraints
Step 4: User selects a due date from the calendar picker provided next to the 'Due Date' field
Step 5: Verify that clicking outside of the modal or pressing the 'Cancel' button closes the form without saving any changes
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The task creation form should be clearly visible, with all necessary fields present and properly labeled. The user should be able to cancel the operation without saving any changes.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Evaluate task completion time for CRUD operations under concurrent users
phase2_test_cases.description: Measure the time taken to perform Create, Read, Update, and Delete tasks when up to 100 concurrent users are interacting with the system.
preconditions: System is running with at least 50 concurrent users
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate a user logging in and navigating to their task list
Step 2: User attempts to create a new task by clicking the 'Add Task' button and filling out the form within 5 seconds
Step 3: System should respond with an HTTP 201 status code indicating successful creation of the task
Step 4: User updates an existing task's title and due date, ensuring that the update is reflected in less than 2 seconds
Step 5: Verify that deleting a task results in immediate removal from the list without any delay
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle CRUD operations efficiently under high concurrency, with task creation taking less than 5 seconds and updates reflecting within 2 seconds.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Test error message clarity when attempting to exceed task creation limits
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that clear and understandable error messages are displayed when a user tries to create more tasks than the system allows.
preconditions: User has reached their maximum allowed number of tasks
System enforces a limit on task count
test_steps: Step 1: User attempts to add another task after reaching the maximum allowed number of tasks
Step 2: The system should display an error message indicating that the user cannot create more tasks due to exceeding their limit
Step 3: Verify that the error message includes a clear explanation and suggests actions for resolution, such as deleting existing tasks or contacting support
Step 4: User tries to bypass the limit by refreshing the page or logging out and logging back in; system should still enforce the limit
Step 5: Confirm that the error message persists until the user resolves the issue
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: When a user attempts to exceed their task creation limit, an informative and actionable error message should be displayed, guiding them on how to proceed.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify backend service handles concurrent users on iOS devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system can handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks from an iOS device.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid JWT token
iOS device is connected to the internet via WiFi
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Task A", "completed": false}
Step 2: Simultaneously send GET requests from 99 other iOS devices connected via WiFi, each requesting a list of tasks
Step 3: Send PUT request to /api/tasks/<task_id> with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Updated Task A", "completed": true}
Step 4: Simultaneously send DELETE requests from the remaining 98 devices, each deleting a specific task
Step 5: Verify that all CRUD operations are successfully completed within 10 seconds for each request
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All CRUD operations (POST, GET, PUT, DELETE) must complete successfully within a 10-second timeframe for all 100 concurrent users on iOS devices.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify backend service handles concurrent users on Android devices
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system can handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks from an Android device.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid JWT token
Android device is connected to the internet via 4G
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Task A", "completed": false}
Step 2: Simultaneously send GET requests from 99 other Android devices connected via 4G, each requesting a list of tasks
Step 3: Send PUT request to /api/tasks/<task_id> with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body {"title": "Updated Task A", "completed": true}
Step 4: Simultaneously send DELETE requests from the remaining 98 devices, each deleting a specific task
Step 5: Verify that all CRUD operations are successfully completed within 10 seconds for each request
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All CRUD operations (POST, GET, PUT, DELETE) must complete successfully within a 10-second timeframe for all 100 concurrent users on Android devices.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify backend service handles concurrent users across different screen sizes and resolutions
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the system can handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks from devices with varying screen sizes and resolutions.
preconditions: User is logged in with a valid JWT token
Device is connected to the internet via WiFi
test_steps: Step 1: Send POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> from an iPhone SE (4.7-inch screen)
Step 2: Simultaneously send GET requests from 99 other devices connected via WiFi, each requesting a list of tasks
Step 3: Send PUT request to /api/tasks/<task_id> with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> from an iPad Pro (12.9-inch screen)
Step 4: Simultaneously send DELETE requests from the remaining 98 devices, each deleting a specific task
Step 5: Verify that all CRUD operations are successfully completed within 10 seconds for each request
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All CRUD operations (POST, GET, PUT, DELETE) must complete successfully within a 10-second timeframe for all 100 concurrent users across different screen sizes and resolutions.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles up to 100 concurrent users creating tasks
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the backend service can handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on task management endpoints.
test_steps: Step 1: Simultaneously send POST requests from 100 different clients to /api/todos with unique titles
Step 2: Each client includes request body: {"title": "Task for User X", "completed": false}
Step 3: Verify that each of the 100 responses returns HTTP status code 201 (Created)
Step 4: Check response bodies to ensure they contain unique auto-generated IDs and timestamps
Step 5: Confirm all tasks created are visible in GET /api/todos response for each user
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All 100 POST requests return HTTP status code 201, each response contains a unique task ID and timestamp, and all tasks are visible in GET /api/todos responses.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify response time for task creation under high concurrency
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system maintains acceptable response times when handling up to 100 concurrent users creating tasks.
test_steps: Step 1: Simultaneously send POST requests from 100 different clients to /api/todos with unique titles
Step 2: Each client includes request body: {"title": "Task for User X", "completed": false}
Step 3: Measure the response time for each of the 100 POST requests
Step 4: Ensure that all responses are received within a maximum of 5 seconds
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All 100 POST requests return HTTP status code 201 within a maximum of 5 seconds.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate correct handling of concurrent task updates and deletions
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system correctly handles concurrent updates and deletions of tasks by up to 100 users.
test_steps: Step 1: Simultaneously send PUT requests from 50 different clients to /api/todos/{id} to update task titles
Step 2: Each client includes request body: {"title": "Updated Task for User X", "completed": false}
Step 3: Simultaneously send DELETE requests from the remaining 50 clients to /api/todos/{id} to delete tasks
Step 4: Verify that all PUT responses return HTTP status code 200 (OK) and all DELETE responses return HTTP status code 204 (No Content)
Step 5: Confirm that updated titles are reflected in GET /api/todos responses and deleted tasks do not appear
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: All PUT requests return HTTP status code 200 with updated titles, all DELETE requests return HTTP status code 204, and deleted tasks are not visible in GET /api/todos responses.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management - CRUD Operations Under Concurrency

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure data consistency during concurrent CRUD operations on tasks
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the system maintains data integrity when up to 100 users perform CRUD operations concurrently.
preconditions: At least 100 user accounts are created and authenticated
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as User A and create a new task with title 'Task A' via the API endpoint /api/tasks
Step 2: Simultaneously, log in as User B and attempt to update the same task's title to 'Updated Task A'
Step 3: Verify that both operations are successful and the system does not return any errors or conflicts
Step 4: Log in as User C and delete the task created by User A via the API endpoint /api/tasks/{task_id}
Step 5: Ensure that all users can still perform CRUD operations on other tasks without encountering issues related to concurrency
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks without data inconsistencies or conflicts. Each operation must be successfully completed with appropriate HTTP status codes and responses.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Backend Service

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Validate mandatory field constraints during task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system enforces mandatory fields such as title and description when creating a new task.
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the application and navigate to the 'Create Task' page
Step 2: Attempt to create a new task without providing a title or description
Step 3: Verify that the system displays an error message indicating that these fields are mandatory
Step 4: Provide only the title field with value 'Test Title'
Step 5: Submit the form and verify that the system still returns an error for missing description
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must display specific error messages indicating which fields are mandatory and cannot be left blank when creating a new task. The creation process should fail if any of these fields are missing.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Backend Service

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify data type constraints for task creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the system enforces proper data types and formats for fields such as title, description, and due date during task creation.
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the application and navigate to the 'Create Task' page
Step 2: Enter a title that includes special characters (e.g., '@#$%^&*()') and submit the form
Step 3: Verify that the system returns an error indicating invalid input for the title field
Step 4: Provide a due date in an incorrect format (e.g., '2023-15-01') and attempt to create the task
Step 5: Ensure that the system displays an error message stating that the due date is not in the correct format
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system must enforce data type constraints and reject invalid input formats for fields such as title and due date during task creation. Specific error messages should be displayed to guide the user on correct formatting.
phase2_test_cases.srs_section: Task Management / Productivity Tools - Backend Service

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Network Interruption Handling During CRUD Operations
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the backend service can handle network interruptions during CRUD operations and recover gracefully.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid JWT token
User has created at least one task
test_steps: Step 1: Send a POST request to /api/tasks with a new task description
Step 2: Simulate network interruption by disconnecting the internet connection
Step 3: Attempt to send another POST request while disconnected, expecting an error response
Step 4: Re-establish network connectivity and retry the failed operation
Step 5: Verify that the task is successfully created in the backend with no data loss
Step 6: Confirm that all subsequent CRUD operations on this task are successful
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should handle network interruptions by queuing or retrying failed requests upon reconnection, ensuring data integrity and no loss of user tasks.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: App Crash Recovery During Task Creation
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the backend service can recover from app crashes during task creation and maintain data integrity.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid JWT token
User has initiated a new task creation
test_steps: Step 1: Send a POST request to /api/tasks with a new task description
Step 2: Simulate an app crash by forcefully closing the application before receiving the response
Step 3: Reopen the application and navigate back to the task creation page
Step 4: Verify that the partially created task is still present in the system
Step 5: Complete the task creation process and verify successful completion with no data loss
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: Upon reopening the application, the partially created task should be visible in the system, allowing users to complete their actions without losing any work.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Data Persistence Across Multiple Sessions and Crashes
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure that the backend service maintains data persistence across multiple sessions and crashes.
preconditions: User is logged in with valid JWT token
test_steps: Step 1: Create multiple tasks through API requests to /api/tasks
Step 2: Simulate a crash by forcefully closing the application after task creation
Step 3: Reopen the application and verify that all previously created tasks are still present in the system
Step 4: Perform additional CRUD operations on these tasks, ensuring data integrity
Step 5: Repeat steps 2-4 multiple times to ensure consistent recovery behavior
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: After each simulated crash and reopening of the application, all previously created tasks should be visible in the system with no data loss or corruption.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system handles maximum concurrent users (100)
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the backend service can handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks.
preconditions: 99 users are already logged in and active
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as user #99 using a valid JWT token
Step 2: Simultaneously attempt to log in the 100th user with a unique, valid JWT token
Step 3: Verify that all users are able to perform CRUD operations on tasks without any delays or errors
Step 4: Monitor system logs and performance metrics for any anomalies or issues when reaching the maximum concurrent limit of 100 users
Step 5: Ensure no user is logged out or experiences degraded service due to hitting the concurrency limit
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should successfully handle up to 100 concurrent users performing CRUD operations on tasks without any performance degradation or user disconnections.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system response when exceeding maximum concurrent users (101)
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the backend service appropriately handles scenarios where more than 100 concurrent users attempt to access the system.
preconditions: 99 users are already logged in and active
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as user #99 using a valid JWT token
Step 2: Simultaneously attempt to log in the 100th user with a unique, valid JWT token
Step 3: Immediately after logging in the 100th user, try to log in an additional (101st) user using another unique, valid JWT token
Step 4: Verify that the system returns an appropriate error message or status code indicating that the maximum number of concurrent users has been reached for the 101st login attempt
Step 5: Ensure no existing users are logged out or experience degraded service due to the additional user attempting to log in
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should return an HTTP status code of 429 (Too Many Requests) or a similar error message when attempting to log in the 101st user, indicating that the maximum number of concurrent users has been reached.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Verify system stability when exactly at maximum concurrent limit (100)
phase2_test_cases.description: Ensure the backend service maintains stable performance and functionality when operating with exactly 100 concurrent users.
preconditions: 99 users are already logged in and active
test_steps: Step 1: Log in as user #99 using a valid JWT token
Step 2: Simultaneously attempt to log in the 100th user with a unique, valid JWT token
Step 3: Monitor system performance and response times for all users while at the maximum concurrent limit of 100 users
Step 4: Verify that all CRUD operations on tasks are completed successfully without any delays or errors for all logged-in users
Step 5: Ensure no user is logged out or experiences degraded service due to hitting the concurrency limit
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The system should maintain stable performance and functionality when operating with exactly 100 concurrent users, allowing all CRUD operations on tasks to be completed successfully without any delays or errors.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles concurrent user limit gracefully
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the backend service returns appropriate error messages when the number of concurrent users exceeds the maximum allowed (100).
preconditions: System is running with no active sessions
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate a 100th user attempting to log in via API POST request to /api/login with valid credentials.
Step 2: Send the login request and verify that an HTTP 429 status code is returned due to exceeding concurrent user limit.
Step 3: Verify the response body includes an error message indicating 'Maximum concurrent users reached'.
Step 4: Attempt another login from a different IP address or device, ensuring it also receives the same 429 status code and error message.
Step 5: Log out all active sessions to reset the system state for further testing.
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The backend service must return an HTTP 429 status code and a message 'Maximum concurrent users reached' when the number of active sessions exceeds 100.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles invalid task crud operations gracefully
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the backend service returns appropriate error messages for invalid CRUD operations on tasks.
preconditions: User is logged in and has a valid session token
test_steps: Step 1: Send an API POST request to /api/tasks with header Authorization: Bearer <valid_jwt_token> and body containing invalid task data (e.g., missing required fields).
Step 2: Verify that the response returns an HTTP 400 status code.
Step 3: Attempt to update a non-existent task via PUT request to /api/tasks/1 with valid JWT token, expecting an HTTP 404 status code.
Step 4: Try deleting a non-existent task via DELETE request to /api/tasks/1 and verify the response returns an HTTP 404 status code.
Step 5: Ensure all error responses include specific error messages indicating why the operation failed.
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The backend service must return HTTP 400 or 404 status codes along with detailed error messages for invalid task CRUD operations.

phase2_test_cases.test_title: Ensure system handles unexpected errors during concurrent user tasks gracefully
phase2_test_cases.description: Validate that the backend service returns appropriate error messages and maintains system stability when encountering unexpected errors during task operations.
preconditions: System is running with 100 active users
Simulate an unexpected database connection failure
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate a scenario where one of the tasks fails due to an unexpected error (e.g., database connectivity issue) while all other operations are normal.
Step 2: Verify that the system returns an HTTP 500 status code for the failed task operation.
Step 3: Check if the response body includes a detailed error message indicating 'Internal Server Error' or similar.
Step 4: Ensure that the failure of one user's task does not affect other users' concurrent operations.
Step 5: Verify that after resolving the unexpected issue, all previous tasks and ongoing operations resume without additional errors.
phase2_test_cases.expected_result: The backend service must return an HTTP 500 status code with a detailed error message for unexpected issues, ensuring other users' tasks are not affected.
